1.content:
Kanya Lereaux fingered the scar hiding at the edge of her hairline while she flipped through songs on her Ipod. She was becoming bored, standing in line, waiting for her turn to check in.

The line to check in at the service desk wound in and out of belted stands, moving sporadically as one or more passengers were registered for their flights. As the balding middle-aged exec in front of her moved up, Kanya grabbed her dufflebag and dragged it a few feet further in line. As she straightened, she untangled her chestnut shoulder-length hair from the earbud wires and checked the departure board. She still had time.

All she wanted to do was get out of Minneapolis. Away from the cold, to lie on the beach and forget the last two years of her life ever happened. She needed to disappear under Raul's radar for a few months and recharge her battery. The gems she had hidden in her clothing would finance her trip if Raul had somehow discovered her offshore bank account and hacked it. It was the least she deserved for all the work she had done for him.

As she dropped her dufflebag, the man behind her bumped her legs with his suitcase and apologized profusely. He was handsome, with dark red hair and a happy sprinkling freckles across his nose. He looked like the grown-up version of a 50's family television show.

Justin Avery's smile and easygoing demeanor hid his aversion for public places and close contact with crowds. As a scientist, he was aware of how quickly viruses could spread in such close quarters. All it takes is one germ breathed into the air by an infected person and...well, he just didn't want to think about it.

He was in desperate need of some downtime after spending 18 months buried in his research. His assistant quit on him, right before he submitted his final work, claiming she'd been flirting with him for a year and he never noticed. Apparently she wasn't as enthused about his research as he was. It was ironic, now that he had some time to take her out to dinner, she was gone.

The couple in line behind Justin were Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Rollings, waiting to check in and depart on their second honeymoon. Things had been rocky in their marriage for quite some time and Victoria was hoping this would help to bring them closer. Edgar didn't see her pack the new lingerie in the suitcase and as she stood there in line, she was relishing the thought of Edgar's reaction when she brought it out. Vicki lost some weight recently and was eager to show off the results.

Behind them was Festus Wheatear, who has saved just enough cash for a trip to someplace warm and is on his way to a vacation of a lifetime. He's been saving all his spare change in coffee cans since 1978 and cashed it all in last week. He borrowed Aunt Hilde's old cardboard suitcase, packed up his spare pair of overalls, a few changes of BVDs and had his brother Richard drop him at the airport. He promised himself that one day he would get off his tractor and see some of the world

The woman behind Festus was desperately trying not to catch another whiff of his cologne, for the first one had proven to be quite overwhelming. She wondered if he had broken the bottle and was splashed. He was quite odoriferous. She grasped her tote with long, peach-lacquered nails and tugged it along. She was on her way to a photo shoot, her itinerary said the photographer was meeting her there. Cameron Ruger was an esteemed photographer, so Taffina Marks was looking forward to this particular trip. In her eight year of being a top model, she was quite accustomed to flying in and out of locations at a moments notice.

~~~As each person in line reached the customer service counter, they stated their desination:

11.content:
Kanya stepped up to the desk, smiling at the enthusiastic woman behind the counter.

"Where are you going today, dear?" the woman asked.

"Bermuda," Kanya replied with a smirk. Where better to get lost than the Bermuda Triangle? Raul will never think to look for me there.

The ticket agent took Kanya's ID to verify her identity. Kanya could tell she was trying to reconcile the picture of the blond-haired, blue-eyed woman in the photo to the chestnut beauty in front of her. She typed a note into the computer and handed her ID back. "Your flight will be leaving from gate A23. The security checkpoint is to your right. You'll need to show them your paperwork and ID. Have a nice flight."

Kanya smiled and thanked her as she walked away, leaving her bag with the agent. She couldn't believe she was on her way out of the country. She had a two-day head start since Raul didn't expect the hospital to discharge her for a couple more days. She got in line at the security checkpoint, excited about starting her new life.

As she neared the front of the line, Kanya noticed an increase in the number of police. She wondered what was happening...
11.title: Security Checkpoint

choices: Kanya spills the beans to rat-man
Kanya plays it cool
111.content:
Then there was no time to wonder about anything anymore, no time to do anything, no time to think, it was all, all over even before it had ever really begun. The police (they were mostly faceless, like Raul) bustled around Kanya, tugging her aside until she was in the middle of them, smothered by them like a cotton ball in the middle of a deep, dark night. She had no doubt that somehow Raul had extended his reach while she'd been gone. These were his goons, of course they were.

Raul had a practical hierarchy. When he was present, he was in charge. When he wasn't, the goons organized themselves according to size. It was best that way. The big guys always took charge, while the little guys kind of hung around the edges of the action like flies circling, or maybe like moths flapping against the scalding surface of a lightbulb, singing their wings. Of course nothing had changed. Raul was nothing if not predictable. Kanya was held in check by the big guys while the wee scrawny ones (they all had slicked-back hair, real bullet-headed goombahs) circled slowly around, cutting off any possible avenues of escape.

One of the big guys spoke. He was, apparently, not only big but dumb, as he was crossing Raul too. "Listen," he breathed into Kanya's ear. "We both know you're had, you've had it. But I'll tell you what. Let's all of us keep playing cops and robbers for awhile, and you give me those goodies you got up under your dress, and maybe I'll see what I can do about getting you out of this thing alive, whattya say?"

It was a good thing for this big goon bastard that the other goons couldn't hear him, Kanya thought, and that was what gave her the idea, the trick to pull to get out of this mess. That littlest bastard, for example, he looked like he could be particularly greedy. He looked like a wet rat in a small blue suit. Kanya shook herself with dignity. Her eyes gleamed, amused.

The big goon took the hint and grinned hugely. He really was dumb. "I want half, too," he said. "What you got from Raul, I want half of it. Elsewise me and the boys do what he says, take you down to the rivah and fit you for a Hefty bag."
111.title: Kanya and the Boys

choices: Jusin tells the flight attendant about Kanya
Justin decides to sit with Kanya
1112.content:
"But what will the others think think about you just giving up on me like that." Kanya asked putting down her bag. The big fellow sneered, "they'll do what I tell them to do." Kanya shrugged and considered the mans words for a moment, "Well I guess I have no choice but to give in and give them to you." The big brute smiled before Kanya carried on, "The only problem is that the jewels are in my bag, and it has already passed through security."

Raul's thug had failed to notice previously that when Kanya had placed her bag down earlier that she had placed it on the conveyor belt that led to the other side of security. Kanya noticed his look of unhappiness. "I could go get them for you if you wanted. The large man shook his head. "I'll do it" He quickly flashed a badge to the security at the airport and they let him across to the other side. Kanya not wanting to lose her advantage passed through the metal detector leaving the rest of the goons behind.

Justin watched the pretty young lady pass through the metal detector before himself. There seemed to be a security officer hassling her, and he wondered what was going on. He put his own carry-on luggage onto the conveyor and watched the two. They seemed to be arguing about the girl's bag. Justin didn't want to get involved though so he tried to avoid eye contact. as he passed through the metal detector. He was about to grab his own bag when he saw the security officer grab the womans bag and open it.

Kanya watched the Thug peer into the bag with anticipation. Dust flew out of the bag and into the goon's face. Kanya quickly turned around and lost herself in the crowd. She heard the Large man sneeze and then she heard a scream but by that time she was already gone.

Justin had his face covered so that he wouldn't catch any diseases from the sneeze. He had accidentally let out some noise from surprise of the event. falling out of the girls backpack, which was now laying on the floor because the security officer had dropped it, were large clumps of dirt.

Justin really didn't want to be involved so he quickly grabbed his own bag and headed toward his gate. Once on the plane, Justin looked at his seat number to decide where he would be sitting. He walked down the little isle until he neared the back of the plane where his seat was. Justin opened his eyes in surprise when he got there however. In the seat next to his was the girl from before.

11121.title: Justin The New RatMan

choices: If Justin calls the mysterious number on his cell phone
If Justin just flies to Bermuda
111211.content:
Kanya was stressed, a bundle of nerves. She was hot, sweating, and feeling quite claustrophobic while she sat in her seat, waiting, begging, willing the plane to just take off, Please! Take Off! she muttered to herself, shifting uncomfortably in her seat. A rather large Samoan woman with a bundle in her arms was making way down the aisle, a flight attendant and that curious gentleman following close behind, though Kanya felt all eyes on her.

She couldn't take the heat any longer, it was suffocating her; she shrugged off her knee-length calf-skin sweater and exhaled with relief as the cool re-circulated air streamed over her clammy, sweat-soaked forearms. The jewels were still securely sewn into the lining of the sweater, tucked safely under her as the large Samoan woman took her seat across the aisle, her baby cooing and gurgling in her arms.

The flight attendant approached Kanya, Justin Avery standing behind her, a confident and cocky smirk across his face.

"Excuse me, miss..." the flight attendant summoned, as another pair of armed security officers boarded the plane and made a beeline downthe aisle. "I'm going to have to ask you to deboard the plane and return to the terminal with these men..."

"Son of a bitch!" Kanya glared at Justin, who shrugged off her death-ray vision, still flashing that smirk.

"Germs..." Justin mumbled. "You're spreading disease.. you are a disease..."

While Kanya was escorted from the plane, Justin took his seat, 17B, next to hers. It was only then that Kanya and Justin both came to the same realization: Kanya had left her jewel-laden sweater behind!

Justin watched along with the other passengers as the men escorted Kanya from the plane. He collected her sweater from the seat next to him, noting its unusual heft, and a few odd lumps in the fabric of the lining. He also noticed Kanya's panic-stricken glances back into the cabin, and her every attempt to free herself from the custody of the security officers, but she remained quiet. She couldn't give away the fact that she had left the jewels, Raul's riches, behind.

Sewn into the collar of Kanya's sweater, Justin found a tag with a 10-digit number embroidered upon it. 481-516-2342... a code? a combination? a telephone number??

When the fugitive was securely removed from the plane, the jet began to slowly taxi away from the jetway. In a few minutes, the pilot would request that all electronic equipment be stowed, cell phones turned off, and Justin would be unable to take any further action for the next 9 hours, while the plane was enroute to Bermuda.
111211.title: Nothing to Lose, Everything to De-Plane

choices: To make an effort to deboard the plane
To continue to Bermuda any way
1112111.content:
Curious, Justin dialed the number from the sweater on his cell phone, absently plucking at a loose string in the seams. He was shocked when the call went through, and a phone rang on the other end of the line. Equally stunning was the sparkling jewel which fell from the hole in the seam where he had pulled the loose thread. Even more surprising than both of those events was the voice when the call was answered; it was that girl he had spoken to briefly in the check-out line, THAT girl... the fugitive!

"Hi, it's Kanya... I don't know how you got this number, but if if you're hearing this message, then you've probably got my life in your hands..." Justin palmed the crystalline blue stone and listened further...

"Ladies and Gentlemen, the Captain has asked that you extinguish all smoking materials and turn off all cellular and other electronic devices, return seat backs and tray tables to their uprght and locked positions..." the flight attendant's command meant that Justin's call would have to end, while the mystery of this girl was only just beginning.

Justin had big plans in Bermuda, grand dreams, world-changing ideas regarding his research; but, this girl, Kanya... she sounded so sincere: her life was now in his hands! He should have never gotten involved! He cursed himself and kicked the seat in front of him.

But, it was too late now, he was involved! No going back!
Or, did he have to go back? The plane had only just taxied away from the jetway, not onto the taxi-way, nowhere near the runway just yet.. he could probably deboard if he made enough fuss....
1112111.title: The Disease or The Cure?

choices: If Kanya makes a break for it, since Raul is still a factor.
If Kanya waits, since the jewels are safely enroute to Bermuda.
11121111.content:
"Hey man, what's your problem?!" a rastafarian-looking dude with dredlocks and wearing hemp-clothing glared over the back of his seat just in front of Justin. "Why you be kickin' my seat, brau?"

Justin saw this as the opportunity he was (not) looking for...

"You mean, why kick your seat, when I could be kicking your ass?" The rasta man leaped from his seat, lashing out with a wicked right cross right at Justin's face. Justin quickly raised his laptop from his lap, and the doped-up dope's fist crashed hard into the silver computer-casing. Justin lowered the case and pivoted his arms back upward sharply, catching the rasta-man beneath his fuzzy chin with the leading edge of technology in Justin's hands.

Before the melee could continue, 2 flight attendants descended from either end of the aisle, along with the on-board air marshall, who helped to detain the combatants until airport security could be summoned.

From inside the airport, Kanya could see the sky-cap rolling out to the plane, though Kanya herself was taken into the security holding area before she could ascertain what the further fuss was all about.

Kanya looked for any opportunity to make her escape from the holding room, and when the security forces were called back to the concourse outside, she thought she'd found her moment. She wasn't worried about being arrested for theft, since the evidence of theft was left on the plane, and would be confiscated by the flight crew or some passenger in Bermuda. But Raul would still have plenty to say and do to her once he was contacted by his people; she was caught between a rock and a hard place, cooped up and cornered. She could take her chances right now, there may not be another opportunity...
11121111.title: Fight for What's Right

choices: To attack Raul and his thugs.
To stand back and watch how it plays out.
111211112.content:
Kanya breathed a little easier now that she had left the stolen jewels on the jet; there was no way Raul would be able to connect her to the theft, the jewels would be written off as a theft, Raul would make a profit on the hefty insurance claim, and Kanya would take her lumps for trying to take flight... she had been down that road before, he couldn't hurt her any more than he had in the past. She would just talk him down, explain herself and offer herself to him and his oafish thugs; after another twisted night of sex-games with the boys, she would work her way back in Raul's good graces again... she exhaled with relief, fully preparing herself to take Raul's best insults and punches, but at least she would still have her life!

Imagine her surprise when the security officers returned to the holding chamber, with a fat-lipped bloody-nosed rastafarian and a bookish scientist geek in tow-- that same smart-looking son-of-a-bitch who turned her in for fleeing security in the first place!! And, he had her sweater in his geeky little hands!!

"Hey dere, sistah!" the rasta man smiled, 3 gold teeth glimmering. "You sure be lookin' too fine to be in a place like dis, girl..."

"Keep it in your pants, pothead!" the security guard demanded, shoving the rastaman across the room, while Justin skittered clumsily toward Kanya. Kanya snarled at Justin, contempt oozing from her pores. The security soldiers shoved rastaman into the next room, while one of them strayed behind to inform Kanya that her guardian was on his way to pay her bail and retrieve her.

"What about me?" Justin wondered, wringing the sweater in his hands nervously, shifting his satchel of documents on his shoulder. "I simply MUST get to Bermuda ASAP! It is of dire importance that I not miss the International Infectious Disease Conference! I'm the key-note speaker!"

"Ya, ya, ya! You sure do talk alot, Mister key-note speaker!" the security guard laughed. "Too bad you did so much talking with your fists on the plane... we'll be back to deal with you, once we get Doctor Dredlocks taken care of..."

HA! Kanya laughed. "You? Hit him? with your fists??"

"Yes.. well, no... I mean... " Justin stammered at the question, asked by the person who should probably hate him as much as the expression on her face told him she did. "It was with my laptop, actually... it's state of the art, you know..."

"Why?" Kanya couldn't help but be curious, noting the torn hole in her sweater lining, it was obvious this strange little man had found her secret stash. "Why would you get yourself thrown off the plane to Bermuda, with all those jewels, tax free and conscience-clear?"

"Because I got your message..." Justin replied with a hesitant grin. "It seemed like a matter of life and death for you, so I came to make things right.. Right?" he passed her back the sweater, and Kanya smiled back at him, uncertain of his honor and honesty, but certainly caught unguarded by his candor and poise. Maybe there are still Good Guys left in this world, she thought to herself...

"WRONG!" a booming voice growled from behind the two, as several no-neck thugs dressed in black suits-and-ties strolled in, followed by a shady-looking Latino wearing Hawaiian print shirt, khaki capri shorts, white deck-shoes and a white fedora. "You! Who the hell are you to be talking to MY GIRL?! You be Wrong, that's What you be, boy!"

"Calm down, Raul..." Kanya sassed, stepping between Raul's thugs and Justin, as Raul approached with such swagger it was sickening. Before he even stopped swagging back and forth, Raul lashed out with a hearty backhand across Kanya's cheek.

"You calm down, bitch!" he snarled. "Don't be getting all up in my face! Not after I get pulled off the yacht at the marina and come all the way out here in the middle of Nowhere to collect ya... "

"We're in Minneapolis, Raul... not Miami..." Kanya laughed off his attack, "Nice threads, papi..."

"What the hell are you doing in Minneapolis, chica? Who you running from?" Raul wondered, no longer even interested in Justin, which is exactly as Kanya had hoped.

"I'm not running FROM anyone, Raul!" Kanya lied with the ease and experience of a politician or priest. "My sister, I told you she was in the heart-hospital up here... I was just on my way back Home when I ran into some trouble with the locals, that's all..."

Raul stroked the goatee on his chin and nodded while Kanya explained herself.
"Oh really? How's your sister's health then? She still breathing in-and-out, I take it?" it seemed a rhetorical question, as Raul kept right on rambling his way unevenly toward his point. "You know, I had a bit of a scare myself, Angel-Eyes... seems we had a break-in of sorts, a robbery... plenty of valuables gone missing from the vault, and You, gone missing as well..." he grabbed her by both wrists and wrestled the sweater away from her with a gruff tug. In one quick motion, he wrapped the light wrap round Kanya's neck, twisted it in his fists and tugged it taut against her throat.
"Funny how that can be taken for granted sometimes... breathing, I mean..."

Kanya's face flushed bright red as she struggled to maintain consciousness while Raul strangled her with her sweater. Justin stepped back slowly, away from the leering Latino and his hit-squad; he was digging deftly through his satchel, and finally found what he was after: a small vial of vile, vitrious liquid, a virus, in aerosol form. There were 7 thugs though, including Raul, and Kanya in the middle of them all; not real great odds, not a great time to be a Good Guy, not at all...


but still...

1112211.content:
"What about you?" Justin asked as he leaned in and reached over Kanya's head, propping open the overhead compartment door to stash his carry-on bag. "I've told you of my filthy nasty secret life as germ-doc, what is it that has you running from airport security?"

"Uhh.. it's a long story..." Kanya hedged.

"It's a long flight..." Justin countered, taking his seat and stowing his shoulder-bag satchel under the back of the seat in front of him.

"Well, disease-control doc..." Kanya sighed, "You got anything in your bag of tricks that will do away with controlling and abusive meglomaniacal fiancees?"

"Ahh.." Justin frowned at Kanya's frank retort, shaking his head sadly. "One of those stories... I should have guessed, and certainly, shouldn't have pressed..."

Kanya shrugged and forced a smile. "It's not your fault, nor your problem... in fact, to hear him tell it, I AM the disease..."

"...and he is the cure?" Justin completed her train-of-thought, and they both smiled.

Justin dug around in his satchel for a moment, while Kanya turned to look out the window as flight attendants made final preparations and the plane rolled away from the jetway, and taxied across the tarmac onto the runway.

"Here! Check these out!" Justin suggested, offering a small plastic container filled with 6 2-inch long 1/2-diameter metallic cylinders. "But, please, be extremely careful..."

"What are these?" Kanya wondered, examining the case. "They look like CO2 cartridges, like the kinds used in seltzer spritzer bottles..."

"Exactly like those!" Justin explained. "Those atomizers contain highly concentrated and specially-formulated strains of germs, from an advanced form of the common cold to an especially nasty strain of the felsh-eating virus... I'm planning on getting a patent to market them for personal security-use... No one should be afraid of the human evil, just as no one should be afraid of germs... we're not all bad, you know..."

Tears welled up in Kanya's eyes at the kindness and concern of this strange man, though she suddenly burst into laughter, which startled Justin.

"My mother always warned me about my flights of fancy, and about getting diseases from the strange men I come across..." she said through tears and chuckles, "And, it looks like she was right!"

The plane rolled into take-off position and all signs pointed to Bermuda...
1112211.title: Goims of Endearment

choices: Raul's goons are at the Bemuda airport waiting.
Kayna enjoys an undisturbed vacation.
11122111.content:
Blab, Blab, Blab says the stewardess as the plane takes off without a hitch. Now air born the plane levels off and the trip is underway. It is a six-hour flight and the passengers settled in for the duration, happily.

Justin was already busy reading a fiction story called, “Cool Elevation” and apparently enjoying the read. Kanya’s eyes were heavy and her body ached from the airport race to safety undercover. She adjusted the back of her seat back as far as it would lower without disturbing the passenger directly behind her. Closing her eyes she became lost to the world in sleep.

After a couple of hours Justin also felt the droop of his eyelids. He pulled the shade on his window and also fell asleep.

The stewardess began passing out the passengers meals around four hours into the flight. Both Kanya and Justin had awakened from their naps earlier and were ready to receive some nourishing substance. Receiving their meals they were pleased to see the supper was to their individually liking. Kanya exclaimed delight at opening hers. For fried chicken and mashed potatoes was her favorite meal. This meal also contained a small lettuce salad along with a dinner roll, and green beans. There was a small container of frozen ice cream and a package of mini-chocolate chip cookies.

“That looks delicious, Kanya.”

“Open yours and see what you have.”

No surprise the dinners were alike. They ate quietly savoring each bite. They both had awakened to starvation. Not really, but it sure felt like it at the time. The stewardess had taken orders for drinks and was delivering the covered drinks to the passengers as they ate.

“I wonder if the stewardess’ get to eat a meal or if they have to suffer till after we reach Bermuda.”

“Look, they are behind that partition. They eat their meal there and if any need arises from the passengers they get up and offer assistance. They probably don’t get to eat a meal through without at least one interruption.”

“I wonder if you will be in the same hotel I’m going to be at.”

“I am going to be staying at a cottage right on the ocean. It is in my travel package. I plan to take advantage of the sightseeing tours that the island offers. I want to see everything there is to see. I also plan to sleep late, eat well and stay up late. I’m on vacation; I’m going to live it up.”

“Yes,” Kanya speaks a bit sorrowfully, “vacation and live it up. I want that too, but first I’m going to just enjoy a good long sleep. I am so tired. I only got out of the hospital yesterday. My body is healing from an operation. I feel great but am so tired.”

The stewardess came and took their trays away; Kanya settled back against her seat and took a long luxurious nap. The next thing she knows is that the plane is descending to make the landing.
11122111.title: If take-off goes on without a hitch

Kanya saves Justin at the last second with an onboard flamethrower
1112212.content:
Kanya sneezed.

Justin looked down with horror as the snot and spittle morphed into squealing green worms!

"Oh my Lord..." Kanya gasped.

"Are these what you'd call... bad germs?" stammered Justin.

"We need to land this plane!" yelled Kanya as she ran up to the cockpit.

Justin shied away from the worms as they slithered toward him. "Do it QUICKLY!" he yelled to Kanya.

Suddenly one of the worms jumped up and latched itself onto Justin's eyeball. He screamed and flailed about, alerting the other passengers to the evil nightcrawlers. Shouting in panic, they ran to the front of the plane to escape. Justin looked behind him with his one good eye; the worms were mulitiplying and advancing, devouring everything in their path...
1112212.title: Kanya Sneezes

choices: a human skeleton
justin jump out
11122121.content:
By the time the crew were alerted of the crawlers, the bugs had multiplied enormously.

The plane that had been so calm just moments ago was now in diastorous chaos.

The passengers were being overun by the evil nightcrawlers, soon the bugs were in the cockpit with the drivers of the plane. The pilots were freaking out and had every intention of jumping out of the plane that very second.

Also which probably brightened up all the passengers day was that they ate metal and many other different materials as well such as human flesh.

Kanya had at least 50 of the bugs on her and by the time she was aware of the bugs it had been to late and they were already biting into her skin and eating it in chunks.

Justin had finally gotten rid of most of the bugs even though he still couldn't see very well he opened the cockpit where he saw the pilot being eaten alive by the bugs and therefore he couldn't steer the plane.

Justing also a fast thinker saw the mirophone that made the pilot be able to communicate with its passengers grabbed for it and yelled"Be calm and find the nearest parashute you can and jump out of the plane i repeat I am asking you to jump out of this plane."

Kanya hearing his awful words rapidly looked for the nearest parachute and did as she was told she put on the akward thing and for all she was worth jumped out and saw that the plane had very nearly reached its destination.

The bermuda triangle was only a few hundred miles away for a plane that wasn't much but for Kanya and Justin that was nearly impossible to get to when the only way to get to there was by swimming!

As she jumped out she also noticed she wasn't the only one who followed Justin's directions and saw that passengers with half eaten faces were also trying there luck from a place that didn't have evil nightcrawling bugs.

111222211.content:
Kenya awoke feeling a tight grip around her waste. Her cheaks felt warm matching the heat she felt when her eyes flew open realizing it was Justin's arms wrapped around her. Touching her face, she became aware it was a sunburn.

To evaluate her suroundings, she shifted her body. Every muscle in her body seemed to scream in protest. What felt like bruises, ached against the hard surface she was laying on. When she tried to move her head, a sharp muscle spasm ran up her neck, causing a painfull ponding in her skull. Yet, she forced herself onto her back, reveling the clear blue sky above her and she covered her eyes with her arm in avoidance of the sun's blinding rays. A cold chill ran up her spine in realization that she was in the ocean, only a large metal fragment of the plane shielding her from drowning in the endless ocean below.

"I-I was afraid you would never wake-up." There was a mixture of relief and concern in his voice.

"The last thing I remember was an explosion and then everything went black. What happened?"

"I'm confused about it myself." There was a pregnant pause. "We were gathering the children and then there was this man, he was holding something in his hand, and looking in your direction, screaming something about the secrets dying. Next thing I knew there was an explosion. While I have been laying here, I've been trying to piece everything together. I remember you telling me you were a Scientist and my gut tells me that you are the one with the answers. So tell me, what secrets was he talking about?"

Raul! Yes, Raul had done this. "I don't know, maybe he thought i was someone else. " She hoped her lie would be sufficient enough.

"I also remember you saying you can't swim." His eyes narrowed and he smirked. "How about I just push you off of here."


"Please, don't do that! I promise, I really don't know." She grabbed onto his shirt, as he pushed her slightly, obviously threatening her.

He pulled her grip free and shoved her closer to the edge. "Hmm, we'll I guess the secret really does die here."

Her eyes widened in fear. If she told the truth, he might push her in the water anyways, because he might be one of them, so she scrambled for another lie. "I-I just work for a pharmaceutical company that studies migraine prevention."

He paused in contemplation and she slithered her body closer to him, farther away from the edge. He shoved her back, this time she slid down the metal wing all the way to the edge. Sharp metal dug into her flesh as she gripped the rugged, broken edge of the plane's wing, as the held on, avoiding falling into the water.

"And what is the name of this company?"

She winced in pain. "Misssion, yes, Mission Pharmaceuticals."

He kicked her, causing her to fall into the water, but one hand retained a grip on the edge. "I'm not an idiot! You called him by name right before you passed out! Tell me the truth before I kick your hand free!"

She pulled her other hand up, grabbing the metal edge for more support. "Look, my hand is bleeding. You're going to attract sharks! I really don't know anything!"

"I watched everyone die, innocent people-- children's body parts everywhere." Tears pooled in his eyes. "I want answers!"

"Al-al-right. I-I work for the CIA. Pull me up and I will explain."

"No, explain now!"

"That dirt I was carrying was evidence about a secret project for population control."

"Population control?"

"The government has been poisoning the soil in rural areas, causing infertility."

"And what were you going to do with this sample,"

"Eventually share it with the public, but the CIA caught on before I could. I've been running from them."

He reached for her hand. "Take it, so that I can help you."

She grabbed onto his hand, pulling herself up. He removed his shirt, exposing his muscular form. Heat rose into her already burning cheaks and she turned away.

He laughed, while he wrapped the fabric around her hand "It appears that we'll be stuck here for who knows how long. Kinda silly getting embarrassed by me taking off my shirt."

"I don't know what your talking about. It's not like I haven't seen a shirtless man before. You just tried to kill me, so I'd say we have gotten to know each other well enough."

"I wouldn't have killed you. I'm a mechanic, not a murderer. Why didn't you just tell me the truth in the beginning?"

"If you were one of them, you could have been lying about me saying Raul's name. Then you would have killed me for sure, the secret dying with me. I figured if you were, maybe you would believe me to be just another innocent civilian. After all, it is strange that a trained CIA agent wouldn't know how to swim."

"Ya, about that, why don't you know how to swim?"

She shuddered as the memory of her childhood family car submerging into the water invaded her mind. Her father grabbed her, pulling her out of the car, leaving her mother to drown. She shook off the image of her mother stuck between the seat and dashboard drowning. " I almost drowned when I was a kid and I have had a fear of water ever since."


He shook his head, while he laughed. "Well, what better way to fight your fear than to be stuck in the middle of who-the-hell-knows, floating on a hunk of metal."

"I'm sure news of the crash is known by now. They'll be searching the Atlantic for us soon enough."

He frowned. "I'm thinking not."

"What makes you say that?"

He pointed up with his pointer finger. " Have you looked at the sky?"

She had, but still looked up to investigate what she might have missed. That is when the cloud moved revealing what looked like a second moon. " What the-."

"My thoughts exactly! Apparently we are not in Kansas anymore, Dorothy."

Her eyes widened in shock. "This isn't real. I'm dreaming."

"I wish that were so."

"How did we get here?"

"If I tell you, then you will really think it is all a delusion."

"Tell me anyways."

"Well, after the explosion, you and I floated for a while in the Atlantic on this very same hunk of metal. Just as the sun was setting I began to drift off to sleep. That is when it happened." He paused. "The ocean opened up into what looked like a whirlpool of sorts. It was like we were sucked into a vacuum that spit us out in this strange place."

Her sore body and throbbing hand was proof of the realness of the situation, but she hoped otherwise. "This can't be real."

"Shall I throw you in the water again to prove it then?"

Her heart began to race. "Please don't!"

He smiled, but she could see the sadness in his eyes. "No worries, I'd rather not die alone. No plans on ridding myself of you anytime soon."

She turned her head slightly to the right, agony weaving in flashing icons across her brain, and tried to open her eyes again. She winced, squinting against the harsh artificial light that seemed to be everywhere at once.

Blinking repeatedly in an attempt to clear her vision, Kanya tried to comprehend what she was seeing.

Rows upon rows of beds fanned out around her and on each bed was another body, many of whom looked familiar to her. Where did she know....

The plane. They had all been on the plane!

She struggled to move again but it was as though she were weighted down. Frantic, Kanya looked at her arms and legs and realized that she was enclosed in a transparent shell from which there was no escape.

Where was she?

11212211.content:
Kanya couldn't quite see over the peering heads who was heading her way but she didn't like the feeling that was getting. A shiver ran down her spine and she shuddered, suddenly cold. She zipped her hoody right up to her neck and slid down in her seat, she didn't want to see who was coming her way. She knew she wouldn't like it. She closed her eyes and tried to zone out. She heard mumbling and muffling, Jason was saying hello to the late passenger and the stewardess was seating the stranger in the aisle seat just opposite Kanya and Jason. Again a shiver ran down her spine as she heard the new passenger thank the stewardess. She knew that voice and the voice make her feel sick.
Slowly Kanya opened her eyes and peered across at the passenger next to her. The minute she caught sight of the floppy black hair, the brown battered leather jacket and the square jawline that jutted out at a funny angle Kanya began to sweat. She gripped the seat and tried to resist the urge to throw up.
Jason leaned over her and regarded the passenger.
"We better land on time mister, I have a very stressed baby sister waiting on me at the other end." Jason was joking, Kanya knew that.
"I'm sorry, this is a kind of last minute thing. I didn't think I would make it. My name's Raul by the way." His voice pierced into Kanya's mind like a blade.
"Jason. Nice to meet you. Now let's get this show on the road." Jason clapped his hands as the engines started roaring.
Kanya looked away, she didn't want Raul to recognise her, that would be fatal. She had gone to such great lengths to change herself, she couldn't fail now. Her newly brunette hair, her green contact lenses to change her eye colour from blue, her spray tan to hide her truly recognisable pale skin and her newly manicured nails to disguise the fact that really she was a tomboy who loved to dig around in the dirt. She had even worn a dress, the second dress she had ever worn in her life. The first was the one she had worn to her mother's funeral, but that didn't really count.
She felt Raul's eyes on her and this made her skin crawl, she wanted to scream, to run, to disembark but the plane was already speeding down the runway.
"Excuse me miss..." Raul was talking to her. She couldn't believe it, what the hell was he doing on this flight?? Could she not go anywhere without him following her.
"Excuse me?" He persisted.
She fumbled around trying to come up with a good accent, she wasn't much cop at accents but she had to try, he would know it was her if she spoke normally, no doubt about that.
"yes, can I help you?" She finally said in a rather rusty English accent. She noticed Jason giving her a funny look but thankfully he ignored it and fished for a book in his bag.
"Have we met before? I'm sorry, but you just look very familiar but I can't put my finger on it." Raul said charmingly.
Kanya tried not to look right at Raul as she spoke, she couldn't give anything away.
"No, I don't think so sir, I have never met you in my life, and this is my first time out of England so I don't think that would be possible to know you. Have a nice flight." Kanya said again in her English accent and at that she turned away from Raul and tried to occupy herself with something else, she knew though that her nerves would be on edge the whole flight and she was worried he would try and talk to her more.
"Did you say your sister is waiting for you Jason?" Raul addressed Jason obviously taking the hint that Kanya didn't want to talk.
"Yes yes, my little sister is getting married." Jason said rather suspiciously. He was an odd character, Kanya thought to herself.
"In Bermuda?" Raul laughed.
"My sister has her quirks. What about you Raul? Business perhaps?" Jason quickly changed the subject.
"My ex girlfriend, she's in Bermuda, and she has something of mine, so I'm going to get it back." Raul said rather sinisterly. Kanya's immediantly flew to her pocket and she was relived to feel the small bag still buried there.
"Hmmm...relationships, waste of time don't you think?" Jason said.
"Yeah, they make you want to go crazy. I'm going to kill Kanya if I get my hands on her." Raul laughed like it was a joke, but Kanya knew that it wasn't and it made her catch her breath.
"Hey isn't your name..." Jason began but Kanya coughed to stop him from continuing.
"Kandy, my name's Kandy, a little similar I suppose." Kanya covered up quickly.
This was going to be a long flight.

The panic in Jason's voice woke her with a start. Frigid air was whipping her hair and oxygen masks were flapping from above. Jason, his own mask back in place, jammed hers over her mouth and nose. So the thumping wasn't just a dream, then?

"I thought I'd lost you there for a moment," he said.

Kanya blinked away the black spots swimming before her eyes and realised how close it really had been. She let him help her get the strap behind her head and took a few deep breaths. Bremuda Triangle. Figures.

"Excuse me," said Jason, getting to his feet, "Now that you're okay, I'm going to see if I can help out. Aircraft engineer, remember?"

Kanya nodded and scrunched up as best she could. Jason squeezed past her knees, winking when he got stuck between her legs. Kanya blushed and looked away, unable to hide a small smile. Just great. Finally meet a nice guy, a hero even, and they were both going to die.

Jason hauled his way forward from seat to seat, grabbing breaths of air from loose oxygen masks every couple of rows. Jen the stewardess was working her way back towards him, a bottle-fed mask like her own in one hand. The two yelled at each other over the screaming wind. Kanya could only catch a few words from Jen: ...strike... ...first class... ...thousand feet... ...hundred miles... ...dead! Jason nodded grimly and followed Jen forward past the curtain into the next section.

Kanya looked around and wondered how many of the unconscious passengers in the other seats were asleep, and how many were dead from lack of oxygen by now. The handful of other people wearing masks were clearly thinking the same thing. The family two rows ahead were okay, the children wide-eyed with panic and their parents in a not much better state. A young couple a few rows back were helping an old woman get her mask on. Two men in suits and yellow masks sat side-by-side in white-knuckled silence. But whole rows of people were unconscious. There were a lot of people with empty seats next to them, and in other rows everyone must have been sleeping. Nobody awake to get their masks on and wake the others.

"I can't just sit here waiting to die," thought Kanya, "Not after what I've been through."

"We have had an incident. The plane has sustained damage but we will be able to land safely. Please stay calm. Please stay in your seats and keep your oxygen masks on."

Jen had come back into this section of the plane. She and another stewardess were systematically moving from one passenger to another. Someone else was with them. It was the man with red hair that had been at the airport. Jen thought, "He must have been seated in first class . . . how many people were hurt? What happened?"

Justin had been working in research for so long that tending to the medical needs of these passengers was a bit of a challenge but the captain had told him that he was one of the two people on the plane with medical training. He was doing his best.

Justin pulled one of the passengers that looked unconsciousness out of his seat. Kanya recognized him as the fella who had bathed in the cologne. Justin started CPR on that man and he called for help.By now the stewardesses were at the far end of the plane. A small slender woman pushed through the curtain from first class and started helping Justin perform CPR on Festus Wheater.

Kanya noticed that the woman's face was tear-streaked. It was Victoria Rollings. Kanya had no way of knowing that Victorian's husband Edgar laid dead from injuries on the other side of that curtain. Victoria had been pressed into service in spite of that because she was the only other person with a medical background. Like Justin, in spite of her BSN, it had been many years since she had done direct patient care. This was a challenge for her in more ways than one.

Kanya's problems with Raul seemed insignificant compared to what was happening right now!

Right then Jason re-entered the cabin. He stepped around the man on the floor and the couple working so hard to help him.. That was not an easy feat for the big man to do. He motioned to Jen.

Kanya looked back in Jen's direction and was relieved to see that the stewardesses had gotten oxygen masks on most of the passengers and they were reviving . . . reviving to face this horror!

The captain's voice was coming over the loud speaker again.

11221.content:
As Kanya walked down the ramp into the sunshine, she could hear the voices ahead of her.

"I told you, I didn't do anything!"

"Look buddy, you're going back, no matter what you say."

"Damn it! I don't want to go back." Kanya could hear the frustration in his voice.

The cop was unsympathetic. "We got our orders. Stop struggling."

Kanya was following the voices down a gravel path. She could hear their shoes crunching in the stone. Fascinated, she stayed close.

"All right. You know your way back to the bungalow. We have to get back to the city. You left the portal open and now we have to spend the rest of the month chasing down residents. When will you people learn? There's no leaving this place. Ever." The cops had doubled back and now passed Kanya on the path. They didn't give her a second look. Apparently she passed as a resident.

She caught up to the resident. He was sitting on the ground in front of a small grass shack. He looked very dejected.

"Are you okay?" Kanya knelt down beside him.

He growled from behind his arms, which were crossed over his knees, with his head resting on his forearms. "Fine."

"Anything I can do?" She felt sorry for him.

He picked up his head and stared at her. "Did you follow those cops down the airport ramp?" He grabbed her arms tightly. "Tell me you didn't." Desperation crept into his voice.

"Yeah, I did. You seemed like you needed help." She tried to shrug free of his grip. It was starting to bruise.

"Are you kidding? You just locked yourself in hell, lady!" He shouted as he shook her, then freed her arms.

Kanya brushed wrinkles from her sleeve. "Of course I'm not kidding. What do you mean, hell?"

He groaned as he stood. "There's no way out of here."

"I'll follow the path and go back out the ramp door." She laughed at his ludicrous statement.

He shook his head slowly. "No, no, it doesn't work that way. The portal only works in one direction."

Dread filled Kanya. "One way?"

He nodded.

"So where is the exit? I need to catch a flight." She stood and looked around. All she could see was jungle and a glimpse of beautiful white sand beach.

He shouted in her face. "There is no exit! They closed the one I found."

Kanya shrugged. "Well, this isn't the worst place to be stuck." She slung off the backpack from her back. She had a bathing suit in there. "I never have time to sunbathe, I guess I do now."

"You don't get it, do you?" He screamed. "It's forever."

She calmly turned and looked at him. He was tall, well muscled and his beard was a shade darker than his blonde hair. "Is that so bad?" She looked over his shoulder at the shimmering blue water. Could this be any worse than the life she left behind when she fled to the airport? "How long have you been here...uh, what is your name?"

"Rick. Rick Norrison. I've been here four years, from what I could figure, once I got through the exit portal." His eyes were pained. "And yes, it is. But I guess you'll find that out, won't you?"

"I guess so." Nonplussed, she tossed the comment over her shoulder as she stepped into the shack to change. "Wanna go for a swim?" She disappeared into the dark recess of the shack.

"Are you crazy?" Rick followed Kanya inside.

When the men noticed that the intruders had given up the thought of escape, they approached quickly. One of them, who seemed to be some sort of chief, adressed Vito, whom he had made out to be the leader of the little group.

The trouble was, none of the natives knew a word of English. Or Italian. And Kanya wasn't even sure what language was spoken in this part of the world.

Vito gestured in the direction of the plane wreck and made signs of something falling down from great height.

The men discussed something among themselves and then signaled the group to follow them, pointing at them with their spears.

11412.content:
Kanya didn't awake until they were almost to the airport. After the turbulence, she'd waited to see if the man wanted to attempt conversation. When he didn't she'd shrugged, leaned her elbow on the window and dozed off. She was curious about his grumpy demeanor, but since she technically should still be in a hospital she was exhausted. The escape had taken a lot of effort, and she hadn't been able to stop running until she boarded the plane.

Though it was a small wonder that she had been able to sleep at all. She'd been looking for signs of Raul or his workers constantly ever since she'd left the tiny apartment he'd let her have. Even when she'd boarded the plane, she kept glancing into the other rows for hauntingly familiar faces.

Now she felt more rested that she had in days. A smile on her face, she put her small carry on over her shoulder, waited for the usual rush of people to pass her in the aisle, and then left the aircraft. She was in baggage claim minutes later, the man with the kid who wasn't his coincidentally by her side.

Grabbing her lone, small suitcase, she checked her watch. The Bermuda Triangle hadn't been a random or rash decision. Her distant cousin lived in a flat nearby, and Kanya was supposed to meet her out front in ten minutes.

"What do you mean, she quit?"

Kanya jumped at the exclamation, whirling around to face the man who'd said it. Big surprise - it was the man she'd been sitting next to. The kid was sitting in a nearby chair, a bored look on his face, while his traveling companion screamed into a cell phone. "Well, find a replacement, or I'll be needing to get a replacement for you, understood?" He then angrily closed his phone and shoved it in his pocket.

She knew it was rude, but Kanya couldn't help but stare at the way the man had carried on line that in front of a small, apparently scared young child. Shaking her head, she almost turned to go when...

"Hey, you!"

Whirling around, Kanya tilted her head in surprise. "Me?"

"Is there anyone else my eyes are looking at? Yes, you!" the man huffed, crossing his arms. "You want a job?"

Amazed at her luck, Kanya simply stared at him.

Mickey took a long drag on his cigarette as he looked at his boarding ticket, the glowing ember eating away swiftly at the paper. He looked up into Kanya’s eyes. His steely blue stare made her feel uneasy but also strangely excited. There was something different about this man. The way he had approached her was brazen and the job offer unexpected, but now he was quiet, almost moody. Kanya waited, expectantly.

She could feel the man's anger almost get the better of him behind her back, but he managed to contain himself.

"Of course," he said begrudgingly.

Kanya turned to face him, "plus expenses on return, of course. You like dolphins kid?" She smiled at the boy, who beamed back a big grin. If she was going to do this, they might as well have some fun.

The man gritted his teeth. "Alright," he said, through a clenched jaw.

He pushed the boy toward Kanya and led the way to the nearest ATM.

"Who is he to you, anyway?" she asked. "You don't look old enough to be his father."

The man shot her a dirty look, but answered the question. "He's my wife's kid. Part of the package. Worst deal I ever made."

What an awful thing to say in front of the boy, she thought. She shot the kid another apologetic look.

"So where's Mom?" she asked.

"Skipped out," the man seethed, angrily stabbing at the buttons on the ATM. "Ran off with some toy-boy and left me holding the baby. So to speak."

Some new toy-boy, she thought, to replace the old toy-boy who was too young to be the kid's dad. Mom was just as much a piece of work as step-dad. She wondered what had happened to the boy's biological father, but thought the better of asking.

The man counted out twenty crisp Bermudan $100 bills into Kanya's hand. Knowing the Bermudan dollar was pegged one-to-one to the US dollar, she didn't quibble over the currency. She tucked the wad of bills into her bra and unzipped the duffle just far enough to get her hand inside. She pulled out one of the three unused mobile phones she had bought at duty free on the way through and turned it on. Punching quickly through the setup, she found and read out the mobile number for the man to enter into his own phone.

"Text me from yours," she said. She wanted to make sure the number she got from the guy was legit. He did. It was; for now at least.

"Alright, it's almost 3pm. We'll meet you back here at 3pm the day after tomorrow. Bring your ATM card, because we will be entertaining ourselves, won't we kid?" She winked at the boy. "We'll be staying at..."

"I don't care," he said and stalked off toward the taxi stands.

"Wow. Alright," said Kanya to nobody in particular. "What's your name, kid?"

"Benjamin."

"That's quite a mouthful, Benjamin. Can I call you Ben?" The boy smiled and nodded.

12.content:
Justin jumped as the tintinnabulation of his ringing phone startled him out of his thoughts. Who on earth would be calling him now. He had no family to speak of and the deal with Mr. Lereaux had gone seamlessly. Not only had he finished his finest work yet, he'd made a load of money in the process. All he wanted was to disappear in to the abyss of none-existence. Unfortunately whomever was calling didn't give a rip about what he wanted. He resigned himself to that fact and ended the incessant ringing. "Hello?"

"Change of plans, Avery. Our transport has gone missing and the boss wants you back here ASAP. We need that antidote." "Looks like you'll be sticking around for awhile after all." He added with a sneer.

Panic gripped Justin in the gut and almost bowled him over. He had finished some incredible work in the last eighteen months, but there was no way he wanted mixed up with these people any longer than absolutely necessary. Besides he had a "friend" waiting for him on the other side of the ocean to leak all of his newfound knowledge to. The rest of the world deserved to know what he knew.

Kanya couldn't help but overhear the terse conversation the handsome "man-sized Opey" was carrying on. He definitely was not talking to a friend. Kanya though he might pass out right there in the airport ticket line. The man was trying to whisper, but even with her ipod on one ear she could hear enough to tell something was up with this guy. His face was the color of snow and the fear in his eyes made even her a little nervous. Not that she wasn't used to being around scary types or seeing fear in the eyes of her father's business associates and clients alike. Just as they were nearing the ticket counter Kanya was surprised by the firm grip on her arm and shocked to see who the culprit was. Mr. 50's himself had a lock on her arm and was pulling her out of line and away from the counter she'd waited to get to for the last 45 minutes. "What in God's name do you think you're doing," she insisted. "I don't know who you are, but if you don't let go of my arm right now, I'm going to make you wish you'd been standing next to someone else in that line." "Now I'm going to miss my plane you jerk..."

"Shut up lady." Her abductor sneered in a tone that belayed his anger, or was it shear desperation she saw in his face? he stopped long enough to face her and utter, "Do as I say and we'll both get out of here alive." He looked to be almost pleading with her, but before Kanya could argue she was being pulled again in a manner that was really beginning to annoy her.

"Look buddy, I don't know what kind of trouble you're in, but I'm not really inclined to be any part of it." She yelled, "Let go, now," and drew more than one glance from passersby as they nearly sprinted through the airport with "Opey" dragging her like a rag doll, baggage in tow. He was definitely stronger than he looked at first sight. He must work out when he wasn't kidnapping innocent travelers. As they neared the exit out to the drop off/pick up area Kanya spotted a couple of faces that aren't easily forgotten. Two of her father’s thugs were sprinting after them, the looks on their faces nothing less than menacing. How on earth had they found her here and who was this guy? She’d never seen him before today, but suddenly she was more than obliged to aide in their escape. Her heart plunged as the goons got closer. There were little more than 30 yards between them and a certain untimely death as unsuspecting travelers were tossed and shoved out of the way.

“Go, Go, Go.” She yelled, now more eager than her captor to get out of dodge. Obviously he hadn’t seen the two gorillas bearing down on them. “Right there, an open cab, come on, let’s go.” Now she was pulling him as he tripped over their forgotten bags and practically fell into the back seat of the taxi. "Ugly and Uglier" had just busted through the exit doors and out into the road as they pulled out of the drive, a little too close for comfort.

"What on earth got into you?" Opey demanded. "I thought I was the one begging you to help me."

"Now just wait a minute. I'm the one that's going to be asking the questions." I said. "Who are you and why did you grab me?" "Those two thugs back there chasing us are friends of my father and none too friendly."

Opey stared at me as if my eyeballs had fallen out of my head. "Do you mean, you know those guys?" He was incredulous at her confession.

"Well, yeah, unfortunately. My father is in a line of business that requires associates that don't mind to do some dirty work, if you know what I mean."

"Oh, dear Lord." Opey looked as if he might pass out again. What was with this guy? Kanya would've worried about this interesting guy more, but her head hurt to bad. Right now, she just wanted to get far away from the airport and figure out where to go from there.

121.content:
Kanya was jostled out of a restless sleep by the honk of a car horn out the right window of the cab. As she came too she was assaulted by the acrid smell of cigar smoke. She sat up from her slouched position and straightened her now crumpled jeans and button down shirt and noticed that they weren't in the city anymore. They were traveling along a country road that didn't appear to be heavily traveled. What she had assumed in half wakefulness to be a car horn was actually the call of some bird that she'd never seen before. She cursed herself for sleeping for so long. She couldn't afford to trust anyone at this point and here she was sleeping with a complete stranger determining her destination. At some point, she now noticed, she'd been transfered to a different vehicle, this one by no means a cab. As well, her traveling companion appeared to have run off on her. She was now sitting on a leather seat. Her surroundings reminded her of being in her father's island mansion. The thick black leather appeared to be heated, unless she was running on warm and the wine bar was stocked abundantly with cognac and crystal, a pricey collection. Apparently she'd been left to fend for herself. Or maybe not.

"Hello, is someone up there?" She knocked on the window separating her and her driver. A tiny crack was allowing clouds of smoke to fill the space she now occupied.

"Hello," she insisted, this time a little louder and with a little more attitude. She was really beginning to get frustrated.

"We'll be arriving shortly. Don't worry." This came from none other than Opey.

"Hey, uhh, arriving where? I don't remember talking about where we were going in the first place...Mr." She stopped herself before calling the man Opey to his face, or at least to the glass. He still hadn't lowered the glass partition.

"We didn't discuss our destination, however, given the circumstances I thought it prudent on my part to get us out of harms way to someplace that might offer refuge for the night. I had hoped you would be rested and ready to discuss our next course of action once we arrived."

"That's all fine and dandy, but where are we going? And what is your name? I'm sure you don't care to hear my nickname for you and if we're going to be stuck together for the night, I should at least know your name."

He was silent for so long she though he might not answer her question, then the glass began to lower and she was met by two sets of eyes staring her down from the front seat. The sight of Opey's friend made her nervous. They were not supposed to be here. All she'd wanted was a quiet escape to a beautiful island and warm weather. She was beginning to wonder it she'd ever get her simple life with no criminals and no father to mess everything up.

"My name is Justin and I'd be obliged if you'd tell me yours as well." He sat silently, she guessed he was waiting for her name so she decided to cooperate, he was being polite after all. Her cooperation, however, was only partial.

"My name is Abby," She lied. No need to give too much information. She was running from some pretty powerful people and the last thing she needed was some goof telling the wrong person where she was. The sooner she could get rid of him the better.

"So, now that we're on a first name basis, would you mind telling me where we're going?" She bemoaned.

"No need," he replied. "We've arrived."

She was shocked by her surroundings. While she'd been focused on Opey, or Justin as it was now, and eyes, also the possessor the cigar that had choked the air from her lungs, they'd driven up from the south and were now emerging at the top of a hill where the road turned into a drive.

"This must be an orchard." She thought to herself. With the sun setting over the far mountains to the west and the radiant collage of color to the east she thought she'd never seen a more glorious sunset. And that was only the beginning. The road they were now traversing wound down into the valley with the trees lining both sides in full bloom.

The blooms, a bright pink and white, were littered over the entire road in a burst of color. The limbs of the trees were so thick with flowers that you couldn't see beyond the next bend. The air smelled of blossoms and apples and had a crisp touch that refreshed her parched lungs of the fresh air they desperately needed. As they continued along she was able to see a house ahead some distance, or better described, a mansion that looked to be old and in shambles.

However, the huge structure was both formidable and elegant at the same time. It must have been quite a sight in past years. As they pulled into the circle drive in front of the house and came to a stop, Kanya noticed another suv tucked away to the side of a detached garage.

The idea of anyone else seeing her made her nervous and for some reason she couldn't shake a feeling of dread overtaking her. As beautiful and peaceful as this place was, something didn't feel right and she didn't like the idea of waiting around to find out why.

1211.content:
Kanya listened as the driver's side door opened, then slam shut. She cringed as the door on her left opened up and a strong arm reached in and jerked her out of the car. "Hey, watch it! I thought we're in this... " Kanya choked off in midsentence after meeting Justin's cold hard stare. His freckles didn't seem too friendly now as his icy green eyes stared into her brown eyes.
Justin grabbed her arm, just above the elbow, in a vicelike grip and lurched towards the drab, rundown mansion's doors with Kanya in tow.

In the front foyer, Kanya was pleasantly suprised at the drastic change in decor. The front foyer was awash in the bright orange glow of setting sunlight. She felt as if she had stepped into Tara, the southern plantation from "Gone in the Wind" There were gilded mirrors and filagree sconces lining the walls, dark mahogany panels lined the lower halves of the walls down to the bright marble floor. Justin stood and fumbled with the keyring but kept his grip on Kanya, he nimbly fingered a single key apart from the rest and tugged Kanya down the hallway. "Just stay cool and you'll stay alive" thought Kanya to herself. They stopped at a narrow mahogany door and Justin slid the key into the lock in the doorknob, twisted his wrist, and pulled open the door in one smooth motion.

The basement stairs looked dark and omnious and a feeling of dread and panic washed over Kanya again and she stiffened up and recoiled. "Now just wait! Whatever happened to discussing our next course of action?" she protested.

Kanya's primal 'fight or flight' reflexes kicked in and she jerked her elbow back as hard as she could and wrenched free of Justin's clenched fingers. "No, please listen..." Justin started to plead but was cut off as the palm of Kanya's flat hand rammed his nose with a sickening crunch. He dropped to his knees and held himself up on one hand while the other hand fingered gently over his now throbbing face, blood trickling between his fingers.

Kanya spun around towards the entrance and bounded out the door like a deer escaping hunting hounds. She started towards the SUV parked in the curved drive when she suddenly remembered that Justin still had the keyring, she abruptly changed directions towards the carport where she had spied the other SUV.

Kanya yanked open the driver's door and clambered inside. She checked the ignition for a key, but there was none. She pulled down the visor but nothing happened. "Life is certainly not like the movies" she muttered to herself.

Looking out the windshield she glimpsed a Honda XR 350 enduro motorcycle leaning against the side of the ramshackled carport. "Just like home" she muttered as she jumped out of the van and raced around to the bike.

She was quite familiar with riding motorcycles, but with the fear of her captors still in her mind, her fine driving skills were shaky at best. Kanya looked over her shoulder waiting for one of the SUVs to come into view.

After about fifteen minutes with no sign of her kidnappers she started to relax. She was still on the country road and she was not familiar with her surroundings. Panic begin to creep back into her mind as she looked for signs of the city or at least a paved road.

She had no idea where she was or where she was going and she had lost all of her belongings or at least she thought she had. There was still a possibility of the her luggage being picked up at the airport and taken to the lost and found. That is if her father's thugs hadn't picked it up to search through.

"Think Kanya, you are trained to handle these things!" She thought to herself.

Then as if by fate Kanya drove right onto a highway. Maybe she was not as far away from the airport after all. She still had a chance to escape her nightmare life of crime. Kanya slowed herself and looked around. To her left she could see the what looked like the city skyline. She was in luck. Before heading toward the city Kanya checked her chest for her hidden gems. Still there. Her pouch were she kept a back-up copy of her passport, driver's license and extra credit card were still in place as well. Having a criminal mastermind for a father did have its perks.

The drive through the city was a breeze. There had been no further signs of her kidnappers and traffic was light. Kanya's spirits were beginning to lift, but as she approached the airport Kanya kept a keen eye out for anything unusual. She drove her bike up to the passenger drop off and casually parked it. Then she quickly raced into the main lobby. She kept her head down, but remained alert.

It was getting late and she would not have many options in choosing a new destination. Kanya made her way to the ticket counter. The only available flights out of the country were to South Africa, New Zealand and Mexico.

Unfortunately she did not have any contacts in South Africa or New Zealand and that would make it difficult in trading in the gems. However, Mexico was out of the question as her father had many business partners spread throughout the country.
121111.title: Kanya's destination dilemma

choices: a journey with Conrad is better than with this lot-First Class
you know nothing about Conrad-decline and stay put
1211112.content:
Kanya approached the desk, quietly glancing behind her to check she was not being listened to.
"Miss, can I help you?" The impatient staff member behind the desk grumbled.
"Yes sorry, I would like a one-way ticket on the next flight to New Zealand." Kanya didn't meet the man's eyes as she fumbled around for her passport and credit card.
"The next flight is in two hours, is that too soon?" The man said tapping away on his computer, obviously putting in all of Kanya's credentials. This made her a little nervous, her passport was fake and even though she had never been sussed out before it still made her catch her breath everytime she used it; as if anyone could read right through her.
"That's perfect. Thank you." Kanya smiled, trying to be as relaxed as possible. There was no way she could screw up now, not this far into the game.
Kanya paid, stashed her tickets in her pocket and left the desk, going towards the departure lounge. Once through security, she decided to get a coffee and some breakfast; suddenly she realised how hungry she was.
With a large coffee in one hand and a bacon sandwich in another, Kanya picked her way through the waiting people and seated herself next to a young, black man who was listening to his ipod. Safe enough, she thought to herself. A quick scan of the departure lounge confirmed she was on her own, nobody was interested in her today. No one had any idea where she was, this made her sigh with relief, she could relax.
Two relaxing hours later, Kanya full, refreshed and cleaned up the flight 407 direct to New Zealand was announced "boarding at Gate 4." Getting to her feet, Kanya made her way to Gate 4.
"Excuse me...Miss...Excuse me." A deep voice from behind Kanya made her jump. She span around and came nose to nose with the young black man she had been sat next to, minus the ipod and holding up a passport.
"Oh I'm sorry, didn't realise you were that close behind me." Kanya flustered and took a couple of steps back, the man smiled and held out the passport.
"I think you left this behind." He grinned.
"Thank you. Would forget my head if it wasn't screwed on!" Kanya gushed, relieved someone as nice as him had retrieved her passport, real or fake.
"Lydia right?" The man asked, Kanya frowned for a second wondering what he was saying, then she clicked, he had looked at her passport, her fake name was Lydia Renolds.
"Yes, hi. Lydia Renolds." Kanya tried to cover her puzzlement and stuck out her hand for him to shake.
He took it and shook it firm. "Conrad Bennett. And sorry for looking at your passport, very invasive of me, but had to be sure it was yours!" Conrad grinned again.
"Well thank you for returning it, I wouldn't be getting anywhere without it. You boarding for New Zealand also?" She asked politely, she didn't really want to be held up but he had been a gentleman.
"Yes yes, going to visit family out there, business or pleasure for you?" He ushered her to continue walking.
"Bit of both really, although I've never been to New Zealand." Kanya replied, aware he was watching her.
"Nice place, my brother and his wife and kids live there, haven't been for a good two years, but decided to tear myself away from work and make an appearance." Conrad chuckled, she liked his laugh, made her relax and feel at ease.
"Well, enjoy your flight Conrad, and thanks again." Kanya waved her passport at him in thanks and turned to the boarding staff.
"And you." She heard him say behind her.

Sat at her window seat, Kanya watched other people board the plane. A tired looking mother, a crying toddler in her arms and twin boys fighting over a colouring book were being directed to their isle seat, great a noisy flight, thought Kanya. Behind them, a couple, the man tall and muscly, the woman blonde and petite, obviously on their honeymoon from the twinkle in both their eyes. Kanya smiled at the sentiment. A short, thin man came after them, talking rapidly on his mobile phone, he looked angry, agitated like he wasn't meant to be there. Kanya hoped she wasn't seated next to him, she couldn't stand huffers and blowers.
"Ma'am..." A flight hostess was upon her all of a sudden, a pretty Asian woman with a sweet smile. "Ma'am, a Mr Conrad Bennett has requested you sit along with him in first class for your journey, would you like to follow me?"
1211112.title: Perfect Getaway

1212.content:
When she stepped out of the car, Kanya dusted herself and pushed ahead of Justin to the front door.

"Abby," Justin called, "Hey, what's the rush? You don't even know where you are!"

"I just didn't feel like being dragged around anymore by an overgrown, outdated, Ope- umm... anyways. Nevermind. I just didn't want you thinking you could bully someone like me around, like you were doing," she mouthed off in a firm yet sarcastic voice. She almost slipped on the "Opey" nickname, but she caught herself, and Justin was none the wiser.

She kept looking around the house. Something was strangely familiar. she reached for the doorknob, and then backed away from it.

"Where are we? What is this place?" Kanya demanded.

Justin reached around Kanya to open the door and quickly pushed her over the threshold. He wasted no time in closing the door behind them.

"Sometimes the best place to hide from someone is right under his nose! Go pick a room and get comfortable. Don't touch anything you don't need to touch," Justin warned.

Kanya proceeded uop the stairs, and upon reaching the landing at the top, saw something she had not seen since she was just a little girl. It was a painting, a portrait of a beautiful young lady, in a traditional formal gown from the late 19th century. It was a pale blue gown, with a full pettycoat, and lots of intricate ruffling, in variable layers on the skirt.

Kanya knew this painting. Kanya knew this dress. She had tried it on when she was little. She had a fight with her father, and had run off to the attic. The dress was in a cherry stained wooden trunk, with elaborate metal work, and fanciful artwork engraved into the wooden sides. Yes, Kanya knew this house. That picture could have been her, but it was not. It was her great, great grandmother.

Kanya was worried if Justin saw the portrait, he would know her secrets. What should she do? If she removed the painting, there would be an obviously empty place on the wall from where the painting had captured the dust. If she let it hang, she would have to find a way to cover the painting, or keep Justin downstairs until it was time to leave.

Kanya quickly took the painting off the wall. Who is this guy and what was she doing here?

Hiding her in a familiar place? Is this guy working for her father? Or maybe he is a kidnapper wanting ransom?

In any case, the life-like art work had to go...it looked too much like her own image. Maybe this "Opie" guy did not know that they were hiding out in her grandmother's villa. Kanya remembered visiting Grandmother DeWitt often when she was a child but after her mother's suicide she never saw her grandmother again.

Kanya decided to go downstairs and get some answers.

"Justin, is it?" She slid her hands along the banister. "How is it you knew to come here? That this was a safe place?"

Justin turned and watched her walk confidently down the stairs. "I know your real name is Kanya." She stopped at the bottom step looking like a bird in flight. Her rumpled clothes and hair now smoothed out. "We don't want you, we want Raul."

Kanya choked back shock. 'What the hell is going on here. How did they find her and who the hell was he? Kanya ran through the possibilities. The gems, it had to be the gems they were after, she patted her coat. "Really, Raul you say? I'm sorry Justin. I don't know a Raul."

"Kanya...we know about the jewels and the off shore account." He turned watching her face turn white.

She swallowed hard. Ok, he might have her, but she wasn't going so easily. "Who are you?" She brushed past him and entered the great room. The large leather sofa and fireplace overwhelming the room. It smelled of her grandmother. Sighing, she sat on the edge of the arm waiting for his response.

"CIA, you're friend Raul will be looking for you. He'll need the money you funneled from him. You don't know who or what he really is do you?"
