As Festus rested weakly on a fully reclined seat, Justin Every was breaking out in cold sweat. There was certainly more to the Spidey guy than what met the eye. His laidback demeanour and feminine voice were masks for a strong, aggressive attitude. Although the gun had been confiscated and the youngster detained, Justin found himself unable to relax.

Justin played the heated argument between the both of them through his mind again. It all began when Eddie started eyeing his documents. Despite clearing his throat and hinting at Eddie that those were private, the Spider kept irritating him with questions. It really grated on his nerves. What gave him the right to peek at his papers in the first place? He had lost his temper and a heated exchange between the both of them ensued. They were shoving each other in the corridor before they knew it, and Justin felt personally responsible for the injury of the poor civillian guy, no matter his offensive perfume.

At the other end of the plane, Eddie-Spider-Gallardo was fuming as well. Things had not gone as planned. Getting Justin Every to the Ararat meeting right away would be more difficult than expected. He had noticed a meeting penciled into Justin's calendar the moment Justin opened his dog-eared planner. After wheedling some information out of Justin, he found out that Justin would be meeting his brother, Thad, immediately after touchdown. They were going to lunch together, at an undetermined location. His boss would not be pleased. Justin would still need to be shadowed after they landed.

13212.content:
Flight 843 landed at LAX for refuel right on schedule before departing for the trans-Pacific leg of the flight to Hawaii. Several massive weather anomalies had to be avoided during the flight, so most of the passengers were strapped in tight to their seats, and some few had become quite air-sick from the weaving and bobbing, and the incidents of turbulence which shook, rattled and jarred the plane mercilessly.

Spider grew more and more tense as the flight progressed, sweating and shaking as he tried to rest and calm down.

"Dude, relax..." Justin tried his best to soothe his shuddering seat-mate. "This sort of thing is perfectly normal..."

"Ya?" Spider stuttered. "Maybe so... but, I'm normally high, and I don't mean at 35,000 feet!" he unsnapped his seat belt and staggered to his feet, stumbling into the aisle.

"Excuse me, Sir!" a bitchy red-head flight attendant approached cautiously from behind Spider. "Please return to your seat and fasten you seatbelts while we navigate this---"

Before she could finish her instruction, the flight attendant and Spider were vaulted from the floor, sent crashing to the ceiling, then almost appeared weightless for a few moments before bouncing back to the floor. The plane took an extreme nose-dive, the engine noise increasing dramatically, whirring turned to grinding as the engines went into overdrive while the pilots most-surely tried to right the craft from its suicidal spinning dive. Passengers screamed, Justin's briefing documents scattered throughout the cabin, luggage fell from the overhead bins, and the oxygen masks deployed.

The plane buckled and quaked, winds and rain pounding outside, the forces of nature and gravity ultimately shearing the wing from the plane as Justin looked out the nearest window, horrified as the wing ripped free. The angle and speed of the dive was too much to safely recover from, the bucking forces of the turbulence as determental to righting the craft as everything else. There was nothing the pilots could do, though they tried their best. Just when they got the plane near-level, lightning flashed and struck the remaining wing, the fuel tank exploding in a fireball, sending the plane into an unrecoverable roll!!

Finally, the plane was ripped apart, two huge sections free-falling toward the ocean.
The cockpit, First-Class and Business-Class at the front of the plane fell harder, faster away while the Coach-Class and tail section caught the rushing winds and slowed slightly in its descent, drifting back away from the front section of wreckage.

Not that it wil matter much, falling from 35,000 feet over the Pacific Ocean, somewhere between LA coast and Hawaii, but, which section are you seated in?
13212.title: Tossed and Lost

choices: They jumped into the slide/raft it from twenty feet high.
They jumped out of the plane, but missed the raft and ended in the ocean.
132121.content:
Justin didn't know it, but he was seated in the very last row of the front half. Terrible screams and shouting were barely audible above the rushing wind and rain. A woman in front of him was screaming at her panicking husband not to take his seatbelt off. Justin never saw what happened to his seatmate, Spider. When the plane broke in two, Spider and the red-headed flight attendant were sucked out into the night sky, never to be seen again. Justin grabbed the oxygen mask and it on his face. At 35,000 feet, he knew that without the oxygen mask on, he would black out. A few people have already passed out from the thin air. It was hard to judge how fast the plane was falling, but Justin knew that once they reached the 10,000 feet mark, the air would be easier to breathe. Justin's mind raced with possible scenarios of how to survive the plane crash.

He knew they were somewhere over the ocean, and thanks to his photographic memory, he recalled a lifejacket was stowed under his seat. The slide/raft was actually part of the door near the front. Justin did not want to unbuckle his seat, but someone had to get to the front door and deploy the raft just before the plane hit the water. Justin tried to look down, but the night sky and the ocean were one and it was impossible to discern between the two. He said a quick prayer under his breath, took the oxygen mask off, and wrapped his feet around the seat legs in front of him. He unbuckled his seat belt and crouched down close to the floor, grabbing the seat legs as he made his way up the aisle. It became strangely quiet as they hit the warmer air above the ocean. People have stopped screaming. Most have already passed out. A few were just frozen in their seats, unable to move. Justin knew time was running out and he had to time it exact. Too early, and the raft will go flying out in the sky. Too late will mean a watery grave for those still on the plane.

A huge fireball exploded in the sky. Justin correctly assumed it was the back half of the plane. It lit up the whole sky, and Justin quickly looked for the ocean through the front door. They were barely a thousand feet away. He shouted to everyone that he will release the emergency exit raft just before the plane hits the water. Justin counted under his breath. He would have to get the raft out when they're barely 100 feet above the ocean. Otherwise it would end up being too far to swim to.

A woman with brown hair and pale freckles in the front row unbuckled her seat belt. She came up behind Justin and grabbed his waist. Justin could feel her hands and arms shaking. Everyone else remained in their seats, watching Justin. They were too scared to unbuckle their seat belts, and Justin couldn't believe they have already accepted their watery fate.

It was time to go. Justin closed his eyes and hoped this would work. If not, at least he knew he tried his best. He released the door handle and activated the slide/raft. The slide/raft inflated within two seconds.
132121.title: Getting to the slide/raft at the front

Justin continues to the lavatory.
1321212.content:
Hoping for the best, Justin and his fellow passenger aimed for the raft and jumped through the open door. Wind resistance grabbed their bodies, immediately slowing them relative to the remains of the doomed aircraft. To Justin, it was just like one of those skydiver films, when one chute deploys and seemingly yanks the person upward and away from the camera at terrific speed.

In the scant seconds before their own impact, they watched the nose of the fuselage smash into the ocean and send a huge spray of water in all directions. A glint of yellow at the edge of the spray captured their attention; the life raft! The storm's wild winds had combined with the falling plane's slipstream to carry the life raft almost to the point of impact. Horrified, they saw the plane tip sideways and directly onto the raft. Their only hope of rescue was gone! They slammed into the water and the woman screamed as the waves closed over their heads...

Justin jerked upright. His heart was racing, he was panting in terror, and his shirt and pants were cold and wet. He looked around wildly, trying to make sense of his surroundings. What happened to the plane's disintegration and the plunge to his death in the cold ocean waters? Then it came to him. The storm had bounced the plane around in the sky so much, he had taken an anti-nausea pill, then stupidly tossed down half the drink he'd ordered before the turbulence had interfered with in-flight service badly enough to stop it altogether. The turbulence had bounced the glass out of the tray table's cup-holder and into his lap, weaving itself into the disastrous scenario that had just been a terrifying dream!

Okay, Justin, get a grip! he told himself. He glanced over at Spider; the man appeared to be sound asleep. He looked around the rest of the First Class cabin, and saw that, now that the ride had smoothed out, the droning of the plane's jets had finally put everyone else to sleep, too.

He decided to go the the lavatory and try to get some of the booze out of his shirt and pants, as he had no wish to smell like a bum the rest of the way to Hawaii, unless absolutely necessary. He climbed carefully over his seatmate, then headed up the aisle. As he reached the stairway to the upper deck lounge, he paused. Do I dare? How long could I look around, before someone shepherded me back downstairs?

Tom Knight was beginning to giggle just a bit. Call it a nervous reaction when faced with a certain cataclysmic event like the wing being sheared off or just plain old psychosis. Either way, Tom was starting to laugh out loud while everyone else on this particular aircraft was screaming their final screams.

Tom was not having a good year. Why just two days ago, he happened upon his wife's BMW in the parking garage at the Four Seasons in Boston. That in itself isn't so bad, but just 2 days before that she had left for the airport telling Tom she was meeting a group of women at a spa in Sedona. Tom had parked his Lexus in the same garage with permission from the chief valet who worked out at Fit-Corp with Tom. They had a similar schedule and often spotted each-other in the weight room and even played a bit of racket ball.

Bernard was a large African American and saw Tom coming through the lobby. "Hey Tom, we workin it out today?"
"Not likely Bern, whats with that Beemer on Level One in preferred parking?" Tom asked.
Bernard looked at Tom with dark eyes and eyebrows heading southerly and said, "Well, let's see, that fine automobile belongs to the general managers newest squeeze and let me tell you.." "That's all I needed to know Benard, thank you."

When Tom started running for the front desk, Bernard had to stop him and almost throw him into the street. "Wait a goddam minute Tom, this is my job you fuckin with, now tell me what the fuck is up an I will help you make it right but don't come in my hotel and start thinkin of bustin shit up!"

"Ok fine Bernard, let go of my neck and I will explain, deal?" Tom asked, barely able to speak through the stranglehold. Bernard let go and took Tom into the Bar. "Tony, 2 beers" Bernard snapped. They sat at a table and after a long sip, Tom said, "The G.M.'s new squeeze is my wife."

At 10:00 tonight they hoppin a flight to Honolulu. That is all I know and now the rest is your business but please take care of it away from this place. I've got kids to feed."

1322.content:
Helen sat quietly lost in her own thoughts, in an aisle seat across from the two men. She looked at them intently, trying to overhear what the younger man was saying, but her own thoughts intruded and kept her from really focusing on the outside world. She could not stop imagining the smell of the orchids and pineapple juice she knew would attack her nostrils the moment she stepped off the plane.

She could almost taste the sweet yellow liquid as she sipped from the paper cups the airport offered to it's guests. She would hold it in her mouth for a moment and then let it slid slowly down her throat savoring every drop. This made her think of the plate lunch she intended to buy the moment she got her rental car. She would head off for Grace's Lunch wagon the only intended stop, on the drive to Coco Head and the house. His house. No! It was her house now and her new life. A new life in familiar territory. Free of chaos and the hectic lifestyle she had lived since she graduated from the University of Hawaii.

She wondered if she still retained the distinction of a local, which was quite prestigious for a haole. She tried to remember how you spelled the Hawaiian word for it, K A M A I N A? or was it K A M A M H I N A? Neither was right, but she didn't recall if she ever knew how to spell it.

This caused her to realize she had a crossword puzzle in her bag and she decided to avoid anymore thoughts of the island she grew up on by diving deep into the puzzle or maybe even some Sudoku. She loved numbers, and numbers were how she made her living since college as the head accountant for a law firm on the mainland.

And now, considering all that her father had left her, the house, the cars, and the money, she would never have to do anything again except count and manage her inheritance. She was set for the rest of her life, you would think she would be happy.

But what would the rest of her life bring? Would it include Victor or should she seek out someone new? Should the whole slate be cleared? Should she rid herself once and for all from the control he had over her mind and body?

The man the kid across the aisle was talking to looked interesting. Maybe she should start up a conversation with him; he seemed disinterested in the conversation which had been forced upon him. Maybe she should just pull out the Sudoku puzzle and spend the next 5 hours oblivious to the others on the plane. Why would the man be interested in talking to her anyway. He didn't know her from Adam and probably didn't care to.

For some reason despite the fact that men always seemed more than interested in Helen, she herself did not feel attractive. This made Helen even more attractive to men. She did not see or hear what they saw or heard. She did not understand why anyone found her special in any way, especially Victor. Victor who had it all. A great law practice, a lot of money, a beautiful wife and daughter and Helen, who was there everytime he beckoned her. Yes, Victor. She knew Victor was her biggest mistake thus far in life.

She opened her bag and removed the Sudoku puzzle book and promptly dropped her pencil on the floor of the plane and it rolled toward the men she had been watching.

13221.content:
Justin heard Spider let out a low whistle just as he was glancing up to see a beautiful woman standing just an arms reach away from him. She had short hair that wisped about her face and the chestnut color made her facial features and golden eyes stand out in a way that could only be described as striking. She smiled and he was sure he could feel his heart melt and drip on his new boots.

She spoke in a raspy but tender voice and pointed to the ground. "I dropped my pencil by your feet."

Spider bent down and picked up the writing utensil before Justin had a chance to come to his senses. "Here you go gorgeous." He smiled a goofy, full-faced grin and Justin rolled his eyes, "I'm Justin," he said "and you are?" She took the pencil from Spider and smiled. "My name is Helen, it's nice to meet you." They looked at each other and for some reason Justin felt an instant connection, a spark that he had never felt with Betty or any other woman. Spider broke the moment of ideal silence, "Yo, Helen, the name's Spider, but you can call me whatever you want." Justin could not believe that people actually said things like that in real life and burst out into laughter. His new, not so refined, airplane pal was one of the cheesiest people he'd ever met. Helen shook Spider's hand, thanked him for giving her the pencil and sat in her seat.

As she leaned back and stared at the No smoking and Stewardess buttons above her trying to get her heart beat back to normal she thought about Justin. The spark she had felt between them had been extremely apparent but involuntary. She looked over only to see him trying to glance nonchalantly at her. Definitely a spark.

After Victor, Helen decided it would be best to let him make the first move. After all, she'd gone after Victor and got him, fallen deeply in love with him before she found out that he was married. She'd been heartbroken but couldn't stop seeing him. Only recently when things had begun to change, when he begun to cease calling her or call her a different woman's name did she put a stop to it. So there she was on her way to Hawaii, avoiding Victor. The last things she needed was another relationship. Or was it?

"Hey," Justin cleared his throat and spoke to her once more.

Helen looked over and smiled at him. He is really cute. "Hey," she replied.

"So... you're heading to Hawaii too?"

"Yep, you been before?" she asked him.

"No, my first time."

"Oh you'll love it. Beautiful beaches, great night life," she grinned.

He smiled back at her, "Sounds like you've been before?"


"Yeah," she nodded.

1322111.content:
Before Helen could answer, a rather loud snore, which came from the middle seat, startled both of them. It was Spider who apparently had fallen asleep and was now shocking most of the passengers in the near vicinity with occasional, but for a tired, over-worked scientist like Justin, much too frequent breathing vibrations. The next one sounded a bit like a very tiny chainsaw, which one would use to cut a branch in half.

As Justin, fascinated and a bit concerned at the same time, was just about to put his hand on Spider's shoulder to wake him up, Helen quickly but gently grabbed Justin's arm.

"No. Let him sleep.", Helen said. "... At least we won't have to hear him talking then."

Justin smiled. It was hard for him to keep it that way, since he was fighting the urge to let out a more noisy laughter. So, he just nodded to her and said: "You're right... He is somewhat of a big talker."

"Yeh... I mean, don't get me wrong. People like that do have their charms, but all in moderation I guess."

"True. Feels like, he has been talking to me for hours, but we've only been in the air for about half an hour, right?"

"Yeah, I couldn't help but overhear some of it. I was sitting here, thinking 'Shut up and give the other man a chance to participate in the talk'... Anyway, you asked, if I could show you around on Hawaii, right?"

"Yes. Yes, I did.", Justin confirmed. But just as he had spoken the words, he thought of Betty. He hadn't called her, since he read that note, and now this woman who was standing and chatting with him had enchanted him completely, although just for a few seconds. But then he thought to himself: I don't need to feel bad about this. All, I did, was ask for a tour guide, and Lord only knows, I could use someone who isn't hyper focused on work for Ararat to show me around in my spare time. This is, after all, hopefully going to be more vacation than work.

"Well, there is a lot to see on Hawaii...", Helen said after a short pause. "... But sure. Do you have anything in mind, in particular?"

Justin thought about it for a while but couldn’t come up with anything. The truth was, as a scientist, studying Immunology, he had never really taken an interest in a lot of new places nor had he bothered to go anywhere special. It just occurred to him now that maybe, this was one of his shortcomings with Betty. He thought of her note again. It flashed before his inner eye. “Sorry I was so hard on you. Good luck in Hawaii.” Was this reconciliation? Regardless, he knew, he had to call her as soon as he got to the hotel.

“Well?”, Helen asked politely. “You’ve been quiet for a while. Everything alright?”

Justin snapped out of his thoughts, as if he had just been awakened by a sergeant, throwing cold water in his face.

“Oh, eh… Yah, right! I… eh. It’s just. Apart from having looked forward to go to Honolulu for over a year, I haven’t actually given it that much thought, as to what I in fact wanted to see.” Justin chuckled with a just slightly awkward smile on his face. “Honestly, I am just glad, I get to clear my head from work.”

“Haha, that’s okay.”, she said with a smile on her face.

“But hey”, Justin continued. “you know the Island, I suppose. Maybe you just pick something, we could see? I trust your judgment.”

“Alright. What is your name, by the way?”

“Justin. Justin Avery.”

“Helen. Helen Garner. Nice to meet you!”

“You too.”

132211121.content:
I nonchalantly drifted out of my seat. I could hear snores as most passengers decided to sleep much of the flight. The perfect chance, I considered, to investigate the carry on luggage. I was intrigued as to what was in the bag that was stored beneath the aircraft. The corriders were surprisingly wide and I was comfortable in my search. After an exhausting stroll from one end of the plane to the other end, I discovered a miniature set of stairs that led to the underbelly of the aircraft. I slowly inched my way down and had no problem finding the luggage in question. Shocking! There was no locking device on it. I opened the zipper.
"Miss?" I jerked my head toward the sound. It was a small child I had talked to on the tarmac. "Are we in trouble?" She inched toward me, her eyes wide. Inside the luggage, my fingers had detected a faint vibration. I winked at the child to stay my own fears as well as hers. I glanced down into the luggage. There was definitely some type of electrical device.
"Come here," I whispered to the child. She obediently moved toward me. I glanced quickly all around until my eyes locked onto one of the emergency parachutes that were placed randomly throughout the aircraft.
She would never have a chance if she had to dive from an aircraft in motion. But if there was an explosion and the aircraft lost its forward motion, the child might have a chance of survival. I locked the tiny chute around the even tinier body. Wordlessly, she nodded as if she understood and stood very still at the emergency door I placed her in front of. I looked directly at the chute cord. I held up each finger on one hand and mouthed slowly, "One...Two...Three.." while my other hand tightened on the cord of her parachute. She nodded with each count. At "five" I pressed her fingers against the metal ring of the chute-pull and she nodded quickly and repeatedly. As I looked away to mentally challenge my next step, "BOOOOM!!!" The little girl was instantly sucked out of my grasp and out the vacuum of the emergency door as it blew out. I witnessed the child as she nodded each count to "Five" and pulled hard. My heart soared as the red, white, and blue silk unfolded in brillant declaration of rescue. The little girl looked directly at me, her tiny hand, now empty, opened and closed her fingers in her grateful goodbye.

God, when I said yes I never expected him to go on for so long! she thought to herself as she washed her face. 141111.content:
Jessica leaned back in her seat and tried to imagine her father. How would he look now? They hadn't seen each other in over six years, ever since the horrible misunderstanding.

It had started as a stupid argument, which she now admitted, she had provoked. If only he'd shown her the same love that he showered upon her son, David. Even if he just gave her a little of that love...maybe she wouldn't feel the need to push him.

Jess closed her eyes. What was she thinking? It was wonderful that David and his grandfather were close. "I sound as if I'm jealous", she murmured.

"What? What's that?" Archie peered at her.

She shook her hand in the air. "No, no...nothing. I didn't mean to say anything. Sorry."

He looked at her, squinting his eyes, and returned to the movie.

Jessica could remember the argument with her father as if it had happened yesterday. She could still feel his large hand as it tightened over her arm. Unconsciously, she rubbed the place above her left elbow.

"You're nothing but a selfish bitch!" he had screamed at her. "You can't even take care of your own son!" Even in the midst of emotion, she had noticed that his English was tinged with a slight Parisian accent. How pretentious he was.

Her father had always been an attractive man. He was taller than average and, as a girl, she had been proud of the way he towered over others. She laughs "yeah pretty much. I'd be surprised if I get any sleep tonight." She laughs again and tilts her head, "so, you're going to France alone? I'm guessing it's probably a business trip."

Justin scoffed, he is embarrassed when asked why he's going to the city of romance alone. Needless to say, he never tells the truth.

What does Justin do?
142222212.title: Hot girl

choices: Go out of the First-Class door and try to track Reimmère down
Hang with his group and hope for the best
143.content:
Jessica had taken the most logical flight she could find to help her catch her target. She knew that he had a fancy for Western countries, tourist locations, and "fine women". He always bought his plane tickets as soon as he'd gotten to the airport, so there was no way to know where Maximilien Reimmère would go next. Lucky for her, she'd guessed the right flight.

She followed him down the aisle, he who was white haired at the young age of 29, wearing his favortie black leather coat and slacks, in which he had ordered some of the most notorious hits that the Agency had ever heard of. They all knew he was a threat, but the issue was how to deal with him and ensure that he be stopped. Such cruelty and disrespect for human life was a threat to national security, growing more intense every minute that it was allowed to continue.

So, Jessica continued to walk up the aisle with the pretense that she was searching for a friend who got a seat mumber that was far away from hers. She noticed the guards he'd brought with him onto the plane, and hoped none of them remembered her from the past. There was someone coming behind her, but she paid him no mind. Her job was to see what Reimmère was up to. She had almost "escorted" him to his seat when her follower made a noise.

"Excuse me, miss, we're about to take off now," the flight attendant interrupted. "Please take your seat and fasten your seat belt."

"Uh, sure, okay," she sheepishly replied. If she was going to help the operation to work, she had to be close to him for the duration of the flight. These first-class passengers had always had a story behind them. Incuding herself.

All throughout the flight, Jessica squirmed and moved about, trying to get back into the Reserved section that had been set up for the airline's extra-special passenger. The flight attendants, as well as Reimmère's guards, started to appear a little suspicious, so she had no choice but to return to her seat.

When she finally returned, she had no choice but to fall asleep and hope no one blew her cover.
The flight lasted about six hours, with the plane flying non-stop, and finally they landed in Paris. Now for the hard part, tracking the target through the plane, and out into the airport, with no support on the ground yet. Her backup would be flying coach on the next flight, which would take quite awhile, so she had to work on her own. The doors opened, but one was specifically opened for the target and his crew.

Jessica had only two choices: Go through the door with the other first-class flyers and hope to catch up with him, or try to blend to penetrate the cover of the infamous, international gangster.
143.title: On Board for Paris

choices: The limo continues to the Paris Ritz, with Jessica in pursuit.
The driver, working with Reimmère, kidnaps Jessica.
1431.content:
The guards were looking all around, and Jessica noticed that each member of Monsieur Reimmère's troupe had a special badge. There was no hope to follow them out unless she got her hands on one.

Instead, Jessica followed the other first class passengers out. No need for baggage claim as she'd brought everything in her carry on. She'd slip quickly through Customs and catch Reimmère at the pick-up.

Outside the airport, she spotted Reimmère getting into a long black stretch limo, windows as opaque as paint. She darted into a taxi, pushing past others with a hasty perdón.

As she sat down in the taxi, she said, "Follow that car!"

The taxi driver grinned, "Oui, mademoiselle." Jessica had been lucky, and she thanked god to get a driver well acquianted with American action movies. Perhaps, before traveling to Paris, she should have bothered to learn French...
1431.title: Pursuit

choices: She decides to postpone the pursuit and just relax
She decides to continue the pursuit

She followed the only way she knew; all the way to the hotel;
Noone was there when she checked in to the hotel; she needed rest and respite;
Would she have time for a bath and could she postpone everything till tomorrow.
14311.title: The Hotel

choices: Jessica picks up the cat suit.  This calls for a ninja-style approach.
She reaches for the lingerie and little black dress.  Time to be seductive.
143112.content:
Jessica thanked her lucky stars for her near-bottomless expense account, then shuddered at the thought of the interview she was going to have with her controller when this was over. The room was tiny, but the furnishings were old-world lavish and the night's stay had a price-tag to match. There were tapestries on the walls and heavy brocade curtains at the french doors (or were they just doors here) onto the tiny balcony. The carpet was thick and luxurious and reminded her of the scene from Die Hard where Bruce Willis learns to make fists with his toes. She heaved a sigh. No time for that now.

She slung her battered carry on bag onto the hand-stitched, quilted bed-spread and thumbed the tumblers of the combination lock. Flipping the bag open she pondered her options. In the bag she had a small but specialised make-up kit; a black lycra cat suit, complete with mask and gloves; a lightweight crumple-resistant business suit, hopelessly crumpled; the indispensible little black cocktail dress; a pair of stylish black pumps, with a reinforced titanium low-rise spike heel; a couple of changes of basic underwear; a set of seduction lingerie including regular and fishnet stockings; a coil of light but strong silk rope and basic toiletries. That, what she had on her, and the contents of the room were all she had to work with.

Remierre was in one of the deluxe suites upstairs, but might not be for long. She had to come up with a plan. She kicked off the sneakers she had worn on the plane, then stripped off her sweater, shirt and jeans, dumping them unceremoniously on the floor. She stood for a moment in her bra and panties, looking at herself in the dresser mirror. With one hand she scrunched her hair up on top of her head, cocking it to one side. Hmm.

She had a plan.

The deserts of Africa

Jessica was always quick on her toes; it was what made her so good at her job. Today, though, she seemed a little out of it. Her head felt a little light, which she didn't understand since she only had water on the plane. But she felt tired and out of it. She drifted off to sleep...totally unlike her character....

When Jessica woke up, she found herself in a strange place.

143121.title: An empty warehouse

choices: Jessica heads for the freight door.
Jessica heads for the other end of the warehouse.
1431211.content:
Jessica quickly took in the situation. Dusty warehouse; aging machinery; empty flour sacks and rodent droppings on the floor. Bakery. Kidnapped. Of course the ropes around her wrists and ankles were also a dead giveaway.

Her head still pounding from the sedative, Jessica heaved herself sideways, toward the slicing machine. The chair scraped a noisy inch. She winced, the sound driving a sharp spike through her skull. Two more feet. This was going to hurt. She lurched sideways again. Her head stabbed again. Ouch. She stopped, letting her head settle and listening in case anyone had heard. There were rodents scratching in the walls, but no sign of people. Better make the most of the opportunity then. Lurch, scrape, stab. Lurch, scrape, stab.

It took 17 agonising lurches to get close enough to the bread slicer to get her ropes to the blade. Getting the ropes moving across the blade was no easy feat either, but after a couple of minutes struggle she was free. She rubbed her wrists and ankles to get the circulation flowing again and looked around. At one end of the warehouse was a large freight door, with a smaller access door cut into it at ground level. At the other end there were two doors; one marked EXIT in large green letters, the other marked OFFICE.

Still rubbing her wrists, she headed for the door.
1431211.title: She scoots up to the machine and holds her wris...

choices: Jessica takes the exit.
Jessica checks out the office.
14312112.content:
Jessica took two jogging steps toward the exit and office doors, then fell back to a walk, her head pounding again. She needed water... and a whole bottle of aspirin. She crossed the warehouse floor, kicking away a rat that scuttled out from under a flour sack into her path. It didn't make her feel any better.

Two doors. The floor was covered in a pattina of rotten flour and dust, but there was a trail of footprints worn into the grime between the exit and the office. Presumably her kidnapper was part of the Reimerre operation; perhaps they used this office for more than just kidnappings?

She reached for the door handle.
14312112.title: Jessica heads for the other end of the warehouse.

choices: Leave Paris and travel to Madrid.
Stay in Paris and attempt to track down Reimmere.
143121122.content:
Pressing herself next to the door frame, Jessica's hand hovered over the handle. After a short moment of listening to near silence, with only the sound of a rickety old ceiling fan turning overhead, she determined that the office was empty, void of any living soul. The handle rattled in her touch but it opened without much more effort than a twist and cautious push. All the while, she made ready to defend herself should her judgement prove wrong, a palm open on her free hand to catch anything that might be thrown at her.

Fortunately, her stroke of luck continued. There was nobody here.... or least, no one alive. On the floor laid two men dressed in expensive suits, faced upwards with their eyes closed, each wearing her enemy's badge upon the lapels of their crumpled jackets. Most likely that they might have been her guards, which explains why she woke up alone and unguarded. From the looks of it, there was no blood, only a violent struggle from how tossed over the room seemed. A quick step over and tap of fingers upon their necks confirmed her suspicions. No pulse. Dead for at least a few hours. Whoever did them in was a highly skilled unarmed combatant, considering the visible damage on their faces.

The aftermath of the scene confused her. If this was a rescue mission, the Agency must have completely forgotten about her. Perhaps one of Reimmere's enemies? A rival? Another organisation? Whatever it was, they certainly did not seem to have any interest in her. Turning her attention elsewhere, Jessica set her eyes around the room and immediately discovered the nearest window smashed open. The fire escape outside the window was simply in clear view for her to make her exit out of the building and onto the street, as if left there in plain sight for her convenience. Turning again, she looked for anything that might help to make sense over what was happening, but there simply did not seem to be much. There were a lot of things messed around in the drawers, evidence that someone had definately been looking for something. She did manage to find out from a ledger that Reimmere used this old bakery warehouse to smuggle in some very compromising materials. It'll prove useful once the Agency finally puts him behind bars. Besides all the fluttering paperwork everywhere, she also managed to find a map with some post-its plastered onto it in the far wall of the room. Instinctively thinking there might be something there, she took a close look.

It was a map of Europe, covered in little dots as if there had been a lot of things pinned onto it. One point had a post-it on it, marked by bright red pins, reading clearly in English: "Delivery". It looks like Reimmere might have an interest in delivering something to a certain city in Spain. Might be worth checking out, but then again, considering how much time she was out, Reimmere could still by in Paris....
143121122.title: Jessica checks out the office.

choices: Head toward the river.
Head toward the traffic.
1431211222.content:
Jessica took a quick mental stock-take.

Best guess, she had been out no more than a few hours. She would have been even more stiff and sore if it had been longer, and she'd be a lot hungrier. Not that she wasn't hungry. These guys couldn't have been dead all that long either, or their own people would have found them and she wouldn't have woken up alone.

Alright then, chances were Reimmère was still in Paris.

Besides, even if that note was a genuine signpost to a genuine delivery, there was no indication of timing and no guarantee that the white-haired psychopath would go to oversee it personally.

She had lost her purse and her carry-on, and along them her credit cards, cash, passport and phone. At least they'd left her her clothes and her shoes. She winced as another stab of pain jabbed through her head. First things first, water and aspirin.

She tore down the pin-holed map and rolled it up, taking care to keep the post-it in its place. She tucked it and the ledger under her arm and made for the door marked EXIT.

Cautiously shoving it open, she found it opened onto a concrete-paved yard, surrounded by a chain-link fence. Beyond the fence was the dingy underbelly of Paris. Every major city has one. The gates were closed and locked, of course, but a line of links near the gate had been recently cut, presumably by the assassin or assassins who had killed her guards. Right now Jessica wasn't complaining - it saved her from having to climb the damn fence.

She shouldered her way through the fence, turned to note the warehouse number, then looked up and down the street to get her bearings. To her left the street ran slightly downhill toward what looked like might be a river. To the right the street rose gently toward a road that was moderately populated with heavy traffic - trucks and vans of various sizes and the occasional car or motorcycle courier. There were no pedestrians to be seen in either direction, nor any shops, restaurants, or homes. Nowhere likely to offer water and painkillers. She'd just have to guess which way to go and try her luck.

She set off in what she hoped was the direction toward a more salubrious and accommodating part of town.
1431211222.title: Paris underbelly

Will Jessica remain a hostage...
1431212.content:
Jessica was gathering her thoughts what happened and what is this place. Her eyes scrutinized every corner and checked any way out. She kicked the chair nearby and rubbed her binded hands to the metal edge and she did another tumbling action to loosen the binded feet.
Alone but very courageous, she was able to remove all the binds in her hands and feet.
Now it is time for me to move and be out of this aweful place.
She felt hungry and she spotted a piece of candy in her right jacket. That gives her much energy.
Whew ! What a mess ! She exclaimed.
She tapped her watch twice and she announced....This is Miss J...I am being kidnapped and housed in an empty warehouse. Over and out..
She tapped again her watched three times and a ray of light appeared facing a wall, and it made a hole, and the hole became bigger and bigger making enough space for her to be totally out of the dreaded dark place.
Now, I have to move fast ! She thought. She noticed that there were two cars parked nearby and she heard voices in foreign language.
1431212.title: Thinks of another way of escape

choices: Her cell phone battery holds and she reaches HQ for support.
Her cell phone battery fails and she must brave the trip back to Paris alone.
143122.content:
As she gasped with the dual effects of hot sand on her cheek and a crick in her back, Jessica froze, mouth agape, after her eyes slowly focused on the easily recognizable creature before her: a desert horned viper. From her short session on desert training in Iraq back in her Academy days, she had been drilled on never wanting to see one of these highly venomous snakes even from a distance; yet, here it was inches before her. As she wriggled on her side in the sand, she realized why her back was so stiff; she was sitting in a chair on her side with her hands tied behind her and her feet bound to the chair's legs. The snake's hissing grew louder as it loomed closer and her chances of escaping it grew more futile, until a Desert Eagle owl flew down and snatched it away for its lunch. Recently returned from the edge of her death, she squinted at the image of the eagle flying away with the snake in its claws and felt that she should spend a moment of silence thanking her small percentage of Aztec ancestors and their currently convenient beliefs. "Thank you, Great-Aunt Raquel."

Next, she thought of her immediate escape and slowly stretched her hands into the back pocket of her jacket where her wallet was. Feeling around behind her back, she found the slot where her credit cards were and slipped out her library card. Jessica had not stayed in one city long enough to visit a library nor had much time for casual reading. She had carefully glued a razor blade, so small that it passes metal detectors and the grimy hands of Mafiosos yet still sharp enough to slice rope or possibly even necks, to the bottom of the card. This she slipped out and slowly tore the knots around her hands to shreds. The ones around her ankles fell similarly quickly.

Sitting up, she looked at the outward, sweeping, circular contrails in the sand and concluded that she had been dropped from a low-flying helicopter. After methodically loosening the crick in her back and thinking about the Desert Eagle owl's close swoop, she added that she had also probably been laying unconscious and still for at least a few hours.

With the sand cleared out of her hair and pockets and her wallet back inside her jacket pocket (the thugs had even left the money; they must be well-disciplined), she looked in all directions and saw nothing but sand dunes for miles. Blocking some of the sun from her eyes with her hand, she looked up at the hot sun and knew that she needed to find shelter soon. She whipped out her cell phone to try to make a report to the Agency and to try and get help. Her International Dialing Plan would work here, but she had a horrible habit of forgetting to charge the phone. As it dialed, she prayed that it had enough charge left for just one call...

Jessica decided to go out the other way to try and catch up with the group. Despite the huge guards, they were easy to lose in the huge crowd. That is, until she saw a man in a dark blue suit walk up to the group. Dark blue? Now who walks around in a blue suit? Jessica, becomng suspicious, walked over and caught the whispers of a conversation
"Monseiur...Oui oui... ze Plaza... tre bien...two. Ou Revoir.
"What was that all about?" Jessica wondered. Something's going to happen at the Plaza Hotel for sure. But two what? People? Guests? Targets, maybe? After all, the guy was a gangster. Hmmm.... May as well pick one, because that way I'll be a little more prepared. People is just too...ambiguous. It's more likely to be...
1432.title: Two

choices: Go to the hotel
Catch sight of Max and follow him
14321.content:
Good! She had been one step ahead of him. Jessica had booked her room at the plaza weeks ago, and upon hearing the man in the blue suit advise what was presumably hotel security of Max's arrival, gave herself a well deserved pat on the back. One thing had not been expected however, two, the man in blue had said two guests at the plaza. She'd have to think about it on the way to the hotel because her boy was on the move.

Jessica wrestled with her luggage at baggage claim and was trying, unsuccessfully, to manuever through the wrong side of the traffic caused by the flood of anxious to-be passengers trying to make their flights. One hard knock from behind and she met the cold tile of the airport floor.

"Par..don..monsura" she heard, the voice now circling and positioning itself in front of her. It was the worse attempt at French she had ever heard. If this was the majority of American tourists, it was understandable why the French detest Americans so much.

"I speak English" Jessica groaned as she stood and tried to regain her barrings in three inch heels. Not the best choice of attire for an undercover operative assignment, but it had been necessary to blend in with the other yuppie deputants that resided in first class.

"I am sorry. This is my first time in Paris and I'm not sure exactly where I'm suppose to be going". He said this without loosing eye contact. His eyes were grey. Not blue, not hazel, but an deep, intriging grey. She couldn't bring herself to focus on the entire face and she sure as hell couldn't focus on his eyes. He had used the secret code.

"Well, perhaps I could show you around, can you hail us a cab?". Her words were quick and emotionless. Jessica had often been told she appeared cold and distant, especially when she was frustrated as hell. Her worse nightmare was coming true. She was stuck in Paris gathering intel on the most netorious international gangster and assigned the one agent she had rather throw off the Ifel Tower. "City of Romance my foot" she tough to herself as she gathered her bag and headed for the doors.
14321.title: City of Romance

choices: Gets out of the cab
Then feels Phil's hand on top of hers
143212.content:
She quickly gathered up her bags and said to the gray-eyed man, "Um, the taxis are this way, follow me" They stay a safe distance behind the group containing Remillaire and his body guards. The last thing Jessica needs is to be recognized, but she can't lose him until she knows for sure that he'll be staying at the Plaza.

They stand outside the airport and the Remillaire group gets into a shiny black stretch limosine. This made Jessica snort under her breath. You'd think the agency could at least get her a car with a driver with what she had done for them so far on this case. But no, she'd have to settle for a regular old Parisian taxi cab.

The gray-eyed man hailed a cab and he put Jessica's bags in the trunk. She climbed in the back seat and told the driver to go ahead and follow the limo in her worst French. She was feeling testy today. Maybe it was PMS. Or maybe it was him....

Once they were both inside the cab, they were free to speak. "I see they've assigned you to help me. I thought I'd be working with Sheindlin." Jessica said with contempt. Even after so many years together, she could never resist his eyes, and after years at the agency, you learn to never reveal that you know someone who has just given you the secret code.

"What's the big deal Jess? We knew this could happen eventually."

"But now? When I'm my biggest mission with a known gangster. Geez Phil, I'm in danger already. And now I have to put up with the danger YOU could get me in! I told them I could work alone"

"You're good baby, but you're not that good. Besides, I'm just here as back up. You'll still run the show - like always" This last part Phil said much quieter which sends Jessica into a rage.

"I'll tell you what Mr. Ex-Husband, I HAD to run the show because you sure didn't want to and someone had to. You had no interest in our marriage, no interest in our relationship, and a whole lot of interest in that damn female agent. So I was the one who did everything while you did nothing. I hope you can manage to do something this time because it could mean BOTH of our lives if you don't!"

Phew, that felt good Jessica thought. She hated to bring up the past and the anger again, but he just brought it out of her. The cab had arrived at the Plaza and, as Jessica had hoped, the black limo was parked right in front of the cab.

Jessica reaches for the door handle and
143212.title: Catch sight of Max and follow him

choices: She finds Phil lying on the floor, knocked out, luggage stolen,a  note left
Phil is sitting on the end of the bed waiting for her
1432121.content:
"Jess..." Phil tried but she waved him away.
"Come on, we've got a job to do." Jess fumbled in her pocket for money to pay the taxi while Phil retrieved the luggage.
"So what's the story?" Phil asked sliding on his shades and slipping out of his jacket.
"We're here on our honeymoon, I've used the last name Harvey." Jess said professionally, not meeting her ex-husbands eyes. She cursed her agency for sending him.
"Yes sir." Phil said a little too sarcastically.
"We need to find out what room Remmiere is staying in.You check us in and I'll get the info." Jess took a deep breath and entered the Plaza Hotel.
The lobby was busy, people were everywhere, it made her feel a little uneasy. She looked for Phil, he was right behind her struggling with the luggage. She nodded towards the check-in desk and Phil nodded back, manauvering his way through the throngs of people to check them in.
Jessica scanned the lobby, she could see woman and men and children but no beefy bodyguards or shifty gangsters. Damn. They were no where to be seen, this meant they had already checked in. This was going to be tricky.

She spotted a young porter, must have been about nineteen, spotty and straight out of college. He was flustered, struggling with some expensive looking luggage, searching for a trolley. Bingo! Jess tousled her hair and popped open a button on her blouse.
"Excuse me Mister..." She said in her sexiest voice.
The porterboy looked up at her, blushing he put the last of the luggage onto the trolley he had somehow aquired and turned his attention to Jessica. He was clearly shy and Jessica knew she could use this to her advantage.
"Erm..can I help you Miss?" The boy mumbled, trying not to look at Jessica's cleavage.
"Yes you can actually, I'm looking for a Mr Remmiere, he's my father. He checked in about half and hour ago but he didn't tell me what room he's staying in." Jessica fluttered her eyelashes for effect, it was working because the boy was going redder and redder.
"Sure, I can help. Follow me." The boy smiled up at Jessica and led her to an empty desk.
"You're very cute." Jessica giggled, she was very good at acting, always had been. The boy giggled back nervously.
He began tapping away at the computer, Jessica glanced around. Phil was still at the checking in desk and there were still no bodyguards to be seen, she was safe. For now.
"Miss Remmiere?" Her attention snapped back to the porter, "your father is in Suite 101, thats on floor 5. He has asked for no distubance this evening, but he is having breakfast at The Lily tomorrow at 8am."
"That's fantastic thank you." Jessica leant down and kissed the boy on the cheek. At that she sauntered away, making sure she swayed her hips for him to see.

"We're room 206, Level 6." Phil joined Jessica in the queue for the elevators.
"Target is one level below but he's not leaving the hotel tonight. Breakfasting tomorrow. We have time. Plus back up will be here by then, we will send them straight to the restaurant." Jess didn't look up at Phil, she was dreading spending the evening in the same room as him if she was honest. They hadn't been alone together since before the divorce and Jessica didn't feel like being alone with him now.

Once inside room 206, Phil put the luggage down and went to make the call to back up, telling them of their plans so Jessica decided she needed a much longed for shower. She stripped down to her underwear, grabbed a towel and closed the en-suite bathroom door. Once inside, she turned on the shower, hot water blasting from the showerhead, filling the bathroom with steam. She sighed, she could relax a little now. Taking her underwear off, she stepped into the hot water, letting it run all over her body and through her hair. Bliss.

After rubbing herself dry, Jessica wrapped the towel tightly around her body, she couldn't risk it coming off in front of Phil, even though he had seen her naked (and made her naked) plenty of times in the past, she didn't want him thinking she was comfortable with him. Then she proceeded to make her way back into the bedroom.
1432121.title: Keep your eye on the Prize

They stick with going to the bar and try and get info from the targets guards
14321212.content:
Phil looked up at her as Jessica entered the room, she could see the instant desire in his eyes at seeing her damp and in a towel. She gave him a stern look and he averted his eyes quickly.
"I suppose I'll be sleeping on the floor tonight." He whispered.
Jessica wanted to be angry at him for even thinking they could share a bed but she didn't have the energy too so she decided to ignore her ex-husbands comment.
"What did dispatch have to say?" Work, a safe subject.
"They will be at the restaurant in the morning, we should look out for Donnie and Burt, they will be in civilian clothes eating breakfast and Rochelle is on the door. All sorted. What's the plan tonight then?" Her mind just could not stop.

This is not just a target Phil, we need to get the files before we kill him. This job is important to me." She turned to face him, he looked gorgeous in the lamp light of the hotel room and some old feelings began to stir inside of her. He was right, she knew that. Her and Phil had always worked better together, that was until they got married. Memories flooded her mind but she shook them away.
"Okay." She muttered, Phil was too close for comfort.
"Good, so lets figure out a plan..."
14321212.title: Old Flames....

Do nothing
144.content:
She grabbed her cell phone from her purse, knowing that she had precious little time to make a phone call before the flight attendants came through to ensure all electronics were shut off. She fumbled a little while dialing, cursing at the stupidity of having a phone with such a little number pad. The phone didn't even ring before being answered.
"Hello, Jessica."
"Seat 15b," she said as inconspiciously as possible, then abruptly hung up and turned the phone off.
She regretted that the same man who had helped her happened to be the target of the day, but such was the way of the trade. She got herself settled in the seat, thankful to be near the window, and braced herself for the familiar commotion she knew was imminent.
The pre-flight checks proceeded as usual, without the slightest hint that something was amiss. Jessica buried herself in her book for take-off, always hating the feeling of detachment coming from lift off. Then, just as expected, she heard a small hissing noise.
She noticed a few passengers look around for the source, but at the moment nobody seemed too concerned. They wouldn't for a few minutes. She, knowing it was coming, was the first to notice the smoke seeping out of the mans bag. The plan was the man would be an assumed terrorist, the plane would be grounded, the man would be apprehended, and members of her organization disguised as cops would deal with him. It seemed a lengthy process for a simple killing, but it was foolproof. Or so she thought. It took her a while to realize that the smoke was coming out of the wrong bag. A bag belonging not to a man, but to a little girl.

Let me know how this turns out," Sarah added.

"Ok, Sarah," Jessica added trying to frantically to remember the address to write it down. "the address was 44 Tabard Street right."

"That is correct. Now don't loose track of time. You might miss your flight," Sara said with a chuckle thinking of what might have happned the first ime to land her friend in the center of London instead of Paris.

"Hey Sarah, I have to go now. I owe you a big one. Oh, how is it going in Houston."

"Well, you hold strong and keep your goal in mind. Then come home! Remember, Widsor is not your husband and you can kick him back home to Houstand anytime. If he wants to return, you are under no obligation to go also. He is your live in and not your life line. Got it!"

"Yes, got it Jessica. Now take a breather yourself. I want the full scoop when you get back."

"Ok dear, You rock girl."

"Cheers dear, and stay out of trouble," said Sarah as she hung up.

Oh dear, Jessica thought. Well, Widsor, the Columbian Sarah had been dating for seven years, was still a thorn in her side. Sarah had wanted him to stay behind in Houston, but he had followed her up and got a job at a local dealership as a mechanic. He was planning on staying with Sarah, and she did not have the heart to kick him to the curb although she could not see herself getting old with him. Sarah just felt like she needed the comfort he had given her as a college student as she stuggled with college and morgage with her parents plight. She had not learned to live on her own and had comfort in Widsor although not happiness. It was not Jessica's problem tonight.

She opened the hallway door and surged into the night being careful to step over the drunk in the way this time. She made it to the street. Just as she was about to hail a cab a wreckless biker sped by and splashed her dress from a puddle in the cobble stoned street leaving her drenched.

Jessica and Andrew road hastily into the misty London night air full of ehilaration of what awaited them.

Jessica thanked the young woman at the counter and followed the bell-person to her room. Initially she had insisted that it wasn't necessary that she be helped but her request was ignored, or unheard. She couldn't actually tell if the silent, slight person she was following was male or female. She attempted to make out the name on the gold toned name badge but it was obscured by a large yellow ribbon which read in large blue print, "We'll make you smile, PROMISE!" Long tawny brown hair covered most of the employees face which was directed toward the floor even as the large cart hesitated and lurched around a corner of the dimly lit hall.

"Room 112", the employee said as they unlocked the door, still looking at the floor.

The luggage was unloaded and Jessica attempted to make some conversation as she searched her wallet for the two-dollar Euro coin she admired at the currency exchange. Placing it in the attendants hand she inquired about the yellow plastic barrier tape she noticed as they passed the neighboring Suite 110.
"Thank you, That room is closed for repair-will there be anything else" the androgynous figure responded.

"Yes, can you direct me to the hotels restaurant please?"

"There is a map on the dresser that lists the pub. Will that be all now?"

"Yes, thank you" Jessica replied. And with that the figure returned from the direction in which they had come, head still bowed down to the floor below.

Jessica freshened herself in the bathroom and thought about how strange the bell-person had acted. Maybe there were just shy, she thought. She could hear their response about Suite 110 replaying in her head. The only lilt that the bell-persons voice made was on the words "That room". Everything else had been flat and monotone with no inflection at all. As she went past Suite 110 she heard "That room" echoing in her head and hoped she would feel better after grabbing a bite to eat.

Sure enough there was "The Pub" as the sign read, just where the map had directed her. She was seated at a small cocktail table by a bubbly young Asian woman whose smile warmed the room and made her feel much more at ease than the bell-person had. "Rose will be with you straight away.", she beamed as she bounced off.

As she waited for a menu she opened her book which slipped out of her hands to the floor. I have heard of not being able to put a book down, she thought to herself, but not being able to hold onto one? As she knelt to scoop up the book a piece of a paper that appeared to be a torn and folded ticket stub from British Airways fell out. The words, "Be Careful" were scrawled on it in small, non-descript, block letters. She examined it for any identifying information such as a name, seat or row number but found none.

Now Jessica was frightened. Instinctively looking around as if the author of the warning would be directly behind her, her heart quickened.

"Excuse me" Jessica said as she left, "The Pub" nodding to the perky hostess. "I'm not feeling well, is there a room service menu I can take with me?" The hostess gave her a post-card sized leaf that read, "THE PUB-TAKE AWAY"

Jessica quickly took herself away to her room. As she approached Suite 110 she heard the words, "That Room" again echoing in her head. Then she smelled a familiar,unpleasant smell. She couldn't quite remember where she had encountered it before. Then as she slipped the key into the doorknob of her room she remembered. She had smelled that obscure, cheap cologne while waiting to check in to her flight to London. It seemed like it had happened a lifetime ago.
Locking the door behind her and latching the safety chain in place she grabbed the chair from in front of the small writing desk and slid it under the doorknob.

1452.content:
Four hours later Jessica cursed her frugal Scottish ancestry for the umpteenth time. Why hadn't she just spent the additional 200 dollars for a direct flight? She'd be in a Parisian taxi by now, getting a glimpse of the Eiffel tower.

Instead she was beyond exhausted, smelled like an old carpet, and was stuck in what had to be the slowest moving queue in Heathrow airport.

"I'm sorry madam, your flight has been cancelled. French Air traffic control are on strike.”

Jessica stared at the woman behind the counter. “What am I supposed to do?”

“I have this voucher for you,” replied the woman briskly. “Now if you go to the counter over there,” she pointed with her ballpoint, “they will find you a room in a hotel.”

“I get to see London?” Jessica perked up.

The woman grinned mirthlessly. “Not quite, madam. We need you to stay in the vicinity. You’re on stand-by which means we need you to be at the airport as soon as possible. So it will be a local hotel. We will call you when we have a seat available. Next please!”

---

She’d been wrong about the first queue, Jessica mused. This one was definitely longer. And she hoped the pungent body odour wasn’t coming from her. She hoped it was the shaggy llama-hair coat being worn by the guy behind her. To take her mind of it she focused on the woman behind the counter. Heathrow seemed to be staffed entirely by brisk blondes. This one also seemed perky. It was depressing.

“I'm sorry madam, but we don’t have many rooms left. Let me see what I can do for you.”

“I don’t care,” Jessica mumbled. “As long as it has a shower.”

The woman wrinkled her nose. “Yes. I quite agree.” She tapped away on her keyboard. “Ah!”

Jessica perked up.

“No. No vacancies I’m afraid,” the woman frowned.

Jessica sagged against the counter.

“Oh. No. Wait,” the woman chirped. “I hadn’t thought about that, you travelling on your own. There’s the honeymoon suite at the Ashford. They won’t like single occupancy, but I suppose you’re a bit of an emergency. It has a Jacuzzi.”

“I don’t care,” Jessica mumbled. “Shower. Bed.”

---

She didn’t recall the taxi ride to the hotel, only switching her brain on again when she reached reception. Jessica asked about getting something to eat.

“I’m sorry madam.”

She was starting to despise that sentence.

“Lunch is served until two. There are some complimentary biscuits with the coffee-making facilities in your room. Now let me tell you how to get to your room…”

Jessica wondered whether the architect for the Ashford Hotel had been chiefly inspired by rabbits. The place was a warren: through a corridor, take an elevator to the third floor, another corridor, down a flight of stairs. She was positive she’d walked through this corridor already, but room 39 remained elusive.

She turned another corner. Finally!

She tried the doorknob and found the door unlocked. Drained, Jessica headed straight to the bathroom where she dropped her clothes on the floor and stepped under a scalding hot shower. God that felt good…

She switched off the shower and towelled herself dry. Yawning, she realised she’d forgotten to ask for an Overnight Kit. No toothbrush. Nothing to sleep in. Normally fastidious, she didn’t care right now. She could sleep naked in a haystack.
1452.title: Lost in Heathrow

14521.content:
Jessica looked at herself in the mirror, God I need some beauty sleep, she thought. Her usual groomed appearance had been replaced by that of a homeless bag lady. God if Mick could see me now, she thought.
Jessica was a woman who enjoyed the finer things in life. However now a toothbrush and tooth paste would seem like life's greatest luxury. The stale taste of yesterday's micro waved plane stew was ruminating in her, making her feel slightly nauseous.

Just as Jessica began to feel thoroughly worn out and ready to sleep this day away, a strange noise coming from the bedroom that startled her. She crept around the door frame, and sneak to turn on the light. As the florescent beam filled the room, a stiffled groan came from a lump in the bed. Jessica froze. "God damm it Susie, I told you I need my rest, now turn that damm light off". Jessica felt as if this was a dream, could this be how jet lag feels? Surely not, maybe she was having a break down, some kind of post traumatic stress after the hell of a day she'd had.? But as the lump in the bed jolted up, rubbed his eyes and screamed "who the hell are you?" with a dirty Texan drawl, Jessica realised this was no dream, no hallucination... their really was a half naked man lying in her bed. "Who the hell am I?" she asked furiously, " I am the lady who has booked this room, now if you would be so kind would you please put on your trousers and get the hell out of here before I call security!".
14521.title: a room for all?

145211.content:
The man had already jumped out of the bed while Jessica had talked and was putting on his pants.
"Let me call reception. I'm sure there must be some explanation for this."
While the man dialed the number Jessica sighed softly and rubbed her forehead feeling extremely tired. She shuffled back into the bathroom and closed the door behind her. She was not going to stay wrapped in a hotel bathroom towel only.
When she came out a man in the uniform of the hotel was waiting for her at the entry of the room. As soon as she turned around the corner of the bedroom into the hall, wondering where the man had gone that she had found in the bed, the man cleared his throat slightly and began to appologise for what had happened.
"It's been a misunderstanding. I know you must be tired as i heared you have just flown in, so i will not bother you with the details. Things have been solved with the other couple and this room is now free for your use. Another member of the staff will come shortly with a fresh set of linnen and change your bed."
Jessica felt relieved that this mishap was solved quickly and that she didn't have to move her stuff to another room or another hotel again. She looked at her watch. 11.30. Even though she had slept on the plane she felt quite exhausted.
Must be the change of timezones, she thought.
She realised the man in the hotel uniform was still standing at the door. "Uh, she closed her eyes trying to think and sighed, okay that's, that's good. Thank you."
The man nodded and left the room. Jessica turned around and walked into the living area of the suite. She looked at herself being dressed again in the same clothes as she had travelled in and grunted. She now wished that she had just stayed in her bathroom towel. She dropped on the nice stylish sofa and stared at the ceiling. What a trip so far. She hoped she would reach Paris soon. Her eyes were heavy.
She yawned.

1452111.content:
The sun was peaking through the trees behind Jessica's bench.
The sky was almost cloudless. The sounds present were a mix of traffic noise, distant conversations, children, birds, dogs and a street musician playing his guitar only 20 meters away from her. Jessica had lifted her head to breathe in the fresh winter morning air and took in the moment.
She exhaled. Her breath was visible in the cold air. She pulled up the collar of her jacket and looked around the park. The Eiffel tower was now a white frosted monument that made it look even more elegant.

Jessica had finally reached Paris yesterday at 5.30PM and had found a small 3 star hotel somewhere in the center to have a good dinner and a good night's sleep.
She had woken up quite early but had at least had a 10 hours sleep.
After a simple french breakfast she had left the hotel to inspect her surroundings.

She grinned. It was strange how she could relax on a bench in Paris like this.
Maybe it was the distance between Paris and the USA that made her feel more at ease. Would Raul be looking for her? She wiggled her nose. It itched a little.
She imagined he would be furious. She had used her creditcard at the hotel to pay for her room. Jessica had been relieved to find it hadn't been rejected...yet.
She hid her hands in her pockets to keep warm and remembered.

145212.content:
"Hunny, the only coffee they had downstairs was decaf, so I had to run across the street to get us some real java," said a mysterious voice, coming in from the hallway.

She paused for a moment, taking in the fresh scene. Jessica stood in a towel with her hand on her hip looking extremely annoyed.

"What the hell are you doing here?" The woman asked angrily, holding two cups of coffee in her hands. She glanced at the man in the bed, shooting him and angry look.

"I don't know who you two are, or how we ended up in the same room, but I'm sure the hotel has something to say," Jessica said, trying to calm herself and the couple down.

"Yeah, they better have an explanation, damn London, baby, I knew we should have gone to Italy, its a hell of a lot nicer there," the man said, sitting up in the bed.

Jessica went to the phone and dialed the front desk's three digit number.

"Hello?" Asked a familiar voice.

"Yes, this is Jessica up in Suite 39. I believe it was you who took me up here. I came from the London airport and surprisingly there is a couple claiming they booked this room as well. And we are all a little confused up here," Jessica said as calmly and politely as she could.

"Ohh goodness, I am terribly sorry. Sophie must have already booked the place and not recorded it," she said sighing. "Jessica, I can understand your confusion, so why don't you come down to the front desk, and I will sort this thing out, so that you can have a nice night's sleep here in London."

"Alright then," Jessica said hanging up. "I'm sorry to disturb your stay, guys," Jessica said a little annoyed. She shouldn't have to apologize. "The lady at the front desk said she'd sort this mess out, so I'll be on my way." Jessica waved good-bye to the dumb-strucked couple, and shut the door on her way out. She heard the woman sigh as Jessica left.

She was a little more than annoyed now. But at least she had gotten a shower in before discovering there were other people in the hotel room. All she needed now was to be in Paris, or at least in an unoccupied bed.

The elevator door chimmed and opened up. Jessica was shocked to see six or seven police officers waiting impatiently by the front desk. The clerk looked scared and a little confused, as she glanced around the lobby. All the officers looked hopefully at the elevator once the doors opened.

1452121.content:
"Good evening officers" beamed Jessica, her mood lightening in the realisation that
double-booking a room was a criminal offence in London. She sauntered out of the elevator and over to the Main Reception desk tossing her wet hair in the direction of the
pale-faced Desk Clerk.

"Looking a little nervous there Edward" she said leaning in to read his name badge.. "and rightly so, I remember you from earlier, you should have been paying more attention to my suitcases and less attention to Sophie The Receptionist, is it any wonder we're in such a curfuffle now...." Edward looked even more scared and very baffled. He stared at Jessica, then at Sophie who was reapplying her lipstick in quite a prevocative way he thought, then at the 7 policemen who were growing increasingly impatient.

"Good evening madam" interrupted one of the policemen. "Can you step this way for a moment please?" "Certainly officer, I'm more than happy to give a statement. You see it all began when my flight to Paris was cancelled in Heathrow, the check-in girl said she would book me into the honey-moon suite of this hotel, I arrived here, Sophie booked me into Suite 39, I had a shower, was about to get into bed only to find Mr and Mrs Jikarta had already booked into the room" vented Jessica, staring pointedly at Sophie, relieved to offload her tale of woe to these very understanding gentlemen.

Jessica noticed one of the officer's scribbling in his notebook, then the policeman who originally greeted her stepped forward and said "Madam, is your name Jessica Nora Adams?" "Yes, how did you know officer? I'm really flattered you London cops go to such great lengths to make us visitors feel welcome, even if....." Her voice trailed off as said officer proceeded to read her her rights "You have the right to remain silent...." "Is this some kind of sick joke?" cried Jessica pinching herself in the hope that she was dreaming. The policeman continued to read her her rights, as another policeman roughly manicled her delicate wrists with handcuffs and the other five officers followed suit after getting one last look at Sophie The Receptionist who seemed to be in a constant state of lipstick reapplication and eyelash fluttering.

Flanked by two of the burlier officers, Jessica was bunched into the back of the white van, which had bars across the rear, a van that was used for only the most hardened of criminials.

1452122.content:
"Freeze!" the police shout, two of them raising their handguns.

Jessica stopped abruptly and pulls her robe tighter around her. "What do they want with me?" she thought frantically.

"Wait that's a woman. False alarm men." one of the men with a handgun answered.

The police relaxed and Jessica padded on to the front desk. She waited as the lady spoke with another guest. As the minutes passed and the woman spoke with guest after guest Jessica became frustrated. What's taking so long, she wondered.

"Miss..." she called as the lady stepped back from the desk.

"Yes madam. What can I help you with?" she said eying Jessica in the hotel's robe.

"Miss...McDermott you double booked my room. Is there some chance I can get another one?" Jessica replied grimly.

"Well let's see. Aha, oh wait..." Miss McDermott mumbled squinting at the computer screen, "Here we go. Room 105A. Here is your key, once you get to the room phone room service to have you bags transferred."

Jessica grabbed the key and stalked over to the elevators. This better be some room, she thought, as people stared at her as she walked by.

She jammed the up button and waited until she saw the arrow above the first elevator turn green. The doors slid back and Jessica walked in with another couple and an elderly man.

Jessica pressed the second floor button and stood back. Once the doors closed she looked around. The elevator was lined with mirrors. It seemed as if dozens of people were inside. Jessica was staring at the walls fascinated when all of a sudden she was pushed against the side. She felt something against her back and panic seized her. She couldn't move.
